objects.name: Data Encrypted
objects.description:
**This technique has been deprecated and should no longer be used.**

Data is encrypted before being exfiltrated in order to hide the information that is being exfiltrated from detection or to make the exfiltration less conspicuous upon inspection by a defender. The encryption is performed by a utility, programming library, or custom algorithm on the data itself and is considered separate from any encryption performed by the command and control or file transfer protocol. Common file formats that can encrypt files are RAR and zip.
objects.x_mitre_detection: Many encryption mechanisms are built into standard application-accessible APIs, and are therefore undetectable to the end user.

objects.name: DragonFly
objects.description:
**DragonFly** is a [Russian](/intelligence/objects/location--1175a3bd-dd53-4a7e-9cdd-50743079025a) speaking cyber espionage group allegedly operating from Moscow,  active since at least 2011. According to the U.S. Congressional Research Service, Dragonfly is **operated by the FSB’s 16th Center for information security**, in which few unit’s officers were indicted in 2017 by U.S. authorities for breaching Yahoo!. **Microsoft MSTIC attributes DragonFly to FSB’s Unit 71330.**

Dragonfly activity originated with the use of **Havex malware** and later, **watering holes against energy and utilities companies in North America and Europe**. 

The **[Federal Security Service](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--9593a575-566d-4f58-96a0-45c95356d511)** of the Russian Federation (**FSB**) is one the main intelligence agencies and the **successor of the Soviet Union KGB**. Its missions are to insure counter-intelligence, internal and border security, counter-terrorism, and surveillance as well as investigating some other types of serious crimes and federal law violations. **In opposition to military intelligence agency GRU, APTs linked to FSB** (such as Dragonfly) **focus more on targeted  cyber espionage, internal and international, than destructive operations** (prepositioning and actual cyber sabotage).

The FSB is also the main agency that **regulates laws** with the aim of **reaching technological independence and information control** in a Russian pseudo-closed internet. In march 2018, FSB asked for Telegram’s encryption keys, a Russian messaging service that provides end-to-end encrypted communications. Facing Telegram rejection, medias surveillance administration Roskomnadzor threatened to shut down Telegram in Russia.

Dragonfly cyber operations used to target defense and aviation companies. In early 2013, the group shifted to mostly **targeting western energy industries** and **companies relying on industrial control systems** (ISC) by using a modular malware dubbed “Havex”. This malware was sent as a validator to the victims through emails, strategic web compromise and trojanized installers downloadable from legitimate ICS software editors websites. 

**While this threat actor has major capabilities in breaching critical infrastructure there has been so far no evidence of disruptive effect of these attacks**. During this campaign Dragonfly focused on intelligence gathering from ICS networks with an unknown intent, potentially to allow a disruptive operation in case of political need. The CISA and FBI have warned U.S. organizations about the possibility of implanting malware into their networks to cause damage in future attacks. 

**A similar group emerged in 2015 and was identified by Symantec as DragonFly 2.0**. There is some doubt about the extent of the overlap between the first and the second operations, that’s why some cybersecurity professionals track them as **separate APTs**. However, the fact that the targets are the same and that some tools have not changed leads us to believe that it is the same threat actor with a slightly different arsenal (the group drops the Oldrea backdoor but still uses Heriplor, Karagany, Listrix). **Dragonfly and Dragonfly 2.0 could be operated by two teams working on the same FBS unit or bureau.**

Technically, the group is known to exploit routers and Public-Facing Application for initial access (Citrix CVE-2019-19781, Microsoft Exchange CVE-2020-0688, Fortinet VPN CVE-2018-13379) but **is not known to exploit 0-day as other Russian sponsored groups**. The initial access is mostly done via spear phishing emails and strategic website compromises with malicious SMB inclusion, allowing the attackers to retrieve NTLM hashes of the victim to be brute forced and then, reused. This kind of malicious inclusion is also done via malicious documents, embedding a malicious remote template requesting an SMB share.



![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/3e65458200ea308f42dff07cfeabdd8e74c9d15bcb748897480a75bb83673814.png)

objects.name: AridViper
objects.description:
**AridViper** is an allegedly Palestine-nexus intrusion set conducting espionage campaigns since at least 2012. The group was observed (by Talos and Symantec) targeting entities in Middle-East, specifically Palestine and Israel, on sectors including government, military, financial, media, education, energy, and think tanks.  
AridViper is possibly linked to Palestinian interests, some cybersecurity vendors **linked the group to the Hamas political organization**.

The group is known for employing spear-phishing emails and fake social media profiles to lure targets into installing malware on their devices.
The group targets Windows machines as well as Android devices using different malware families such as [MICROPSIA](/intelligence/objects/malware--a7981214-723d-496b-bbb6-4caecb324457), [AridGopher](/intelligence/objects/malware--63a69d30-9438-42d8-8685-57d6b27663a2) and [PyMICROPSIA](/intelligence/objects/malware--fea3f711-49da-42be-9341-3645cb4a7ffd).

objects.name: Lazarus Group
objects.description:
Lazarus Group is a **[North Korea](/intelligence/objects/location--41e6f61f-d388-4317-b583-3d508b1d7776)-nexus** Intrusion Set, active since at least **2009**. Of note, as North Korean intrusion sets  display significant overlap and shared toolbox, the name Lazarus Group used in open sources is known to encompass a broad range of activity. SEKOIA complies to differentiate North Korea aligned intrusion sets as much as possible and consider Bluenoroff, APT37, and KIMSUKY to be differentiated. 

Lazarus is a dual-hatted Intrusion Set, whose primary motivation is **espionage**, with a secondary motivation pertaining to **revenue generation**. While heavily relying on **wipers** in **destructive** attacks against the U.S. and South Korea **until 2015**, Lazarus since evolved to leverage signature malware including **ransomware** (VHD), **trojanized applications** (DeFi wallet, Dacls RAT), **spyware** (Manuscrypt) and framework (MATA) alongside **open source and zero-day vulnerabilities**, in lucrative and espionage campaigns against a broader victimology.

Longstading **verticals of interest include the defence industry as well as finance and cryptocurrencies platforms and users**. Based on past observed activities, notably in surge capacity times such as Covid epidemic, Lazarus, similarily to Kimsuky, can temporarily shift their focus to target unusual sectors and / or countries. In 2021, Lazarus was also seen conducting a campaign against **security researchers**, notably leveraging **social networks** and **supply chain attack**.

To date, observed Lazarus victimology includes - defence and military contractors and companies, cryptocurrency, media, banks, freight logistics, healthcare, chemical industry,  in Europe, Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, the Middle East, Latin America and the U.S..

objects.name: Russian People’s Cyber Army
objects.description:
**People's Cyber army** (formerly known as Cyber Army of Russia) is a collective of Russian hacktivist conducting **DDoS campaigns** against Ukrainian targets, in the context of the Russo-Ukrainian conflict that started in February 2022. This collective is an analog of the Ukrainian hacktivist group IT Army. They claim to be purely **politically-motivated** and denounced lucrative purposes on several occasions on their Telegram channel. In August 2022, they claim to include more than **8,200 volunteer members**. Additional, yet **marginal, activities include influence operations** carried out on social networks, notably commenting on International Organizations's Youtube and Twitter accounts.
On 29 September 2022, Mandiant assesses with moderate confidence that the **moderators of CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn are at least coordinating with APT28** due to the **timing of the leaks** and the group’s connection to Xaknet. This was confirmed by GTAG in April 2023.
On a signifiant part of data leaks on Telegram channel CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn, Mandiant directly or indirectly observed **APT28 intrusion operations on the same Ukrainian victim's networks within 24 hours preceding the leaks**.
Their main **Telegram channels** are :
@CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn Secondary @CyberArmyofRussia @CyberArmyInvite_bot Link to the general chat - https://[t.]me/+f1VUYWxbeuwxNjli Their Twitter account @CyberArmyRussia is now suspended.
Open Source mention that People's Cyber Army would be one of the divisions created under the **Cossack Counterintelligence Service**.
People's Cyber army targets are **circumscribed to Ukraine** and notably include **websites** of the following :
* Media * National, regional and local governement-related entities (Congress, ministry of Internal Affairs) * Law enforcement * Energy-related entities (distribution, production, and extraction of oil and gas and nuclear energy) * Transportation * Manufacturing * Military, including military support companies, military academies, military forces * Defence industrial base * Retail * Banking * Printing services * Ukrainian IT Army

objects.name: APT28
objects.description:
**APT28** is a Russia-nexus intrusion set attributed by Western intelligence services to [Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU)](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--ca2f2a66-74c5-4c68-80a3-ec43478d8f50**) 85th Main Special Service Center** (GTsSS) Military **Unit 26165**. This intrusion set, which started its operations in 2004 against occidental Military networks, is especially known for its hybrid operations on the sidelines of armed conflict and diplomatic crises related to Russia. 

It was in 2014 with a report called "Operation Pawn Storm" released by Trend Micro that the  public became aware of this intrusion set. Since then, APT28 has made the headlines during several espionage, destabilization and sabotage operations.

Its intrusion techniques are most often singular, such as spear phishing using a malicious attachment or leading to a watering hole, credentials theft by using malicious emails associated with domain typo-squatting or dns hijacking. APT28 is also known for achieving VPN / RDP frontal compromises and IOT compromises in order to get a foothold in the targeted networks. This intrusion set is also suspected to have achieved at least one attack by a supply chain in central Asia.

The APT28 intrusion set was designated historically by its tools, that are for a large part developed internally, such as the malicious code X-TUNNEL, the X-AGENT backdoor, the UEFI rootkit dubbed “[LoJax](/intelligence/objects/malware--293bc1ee-5d2e-4d07-8e78-e2c31df62cf9)", or the CORESHELL validator. Using these tools mostly during its operations, APT28 seems to have left them for the use of open source offensive tools.

Other tools targeting different platforms have also been identified such as an [Android implant](/intelligence/objects/malware--4c8a56d1-4bb9-4827-ad2d-faa402cdefa4) spread to Ukrainian gunners on the Donbass Front as well as IOS and OSX versions of the X-AGENT implant.

The operations of the APT28 intrusion set were closely linked to the operations of another threat actor dubbed "[Sandworm](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--f29bd8cc-1cea-497c-ac3f-8d590b95c9d6)", "Blackenergy" or "Hades". This second intrusion set has been attributed to another GRU unit, the unit 74455. It seems that these two threat actors worked together during several operations, APT28 giving the lead to Sandworm on some destabilization campaigns (Ukrainian crisis, US and French presidential elections). 

The distinction between these two intrusion sets is most often done from the tools used, Sandworm preferring open source offensive tools such as [Empire](/intelligence/objects/malware--43650dc8-980b-4b5f-9646-476cccbae2f7) or [Metasploit](/intelligence/objects/tool--57f456d7-20b2-4609-859e-54d9238946f0) during its operations. Which is now harder to perform now since APT28 also switched to open source tools.

### Campaigns

APT28 has become famous for its destabilization campaigns during several crisis contexts since 2013. APT28 was customary in the creation of fake hacktivist groups to allow the spreading of stolen information (emails, documents) from its victims or the claim of successful attacks. APT28 is also known for modifying stolen documents before making them public to increase the impact of destabilization. Here is a non-exhaustive list of several false flags and hacktivist groups operated by APT28, sometimes with the support of the Sandworm intrusion set.

|  Avatar/FalseFalg/Operation  | Context |  Use |  Attribution confidence |
|----------|---------------|-------|----------|
| CyberBerkut | Ukrainian crisis | Sabotage, leaks | High | 
| YemeniCyberArmy | Yemeni crisis | Leaks | High | 
| SyrianCyberArmy | Syrian crisis | DDoS attacks | High | 
| CyberCaliphate | Russia-occident tensions | Sabotage, Leaks | High | 
| Fancy Bear | Olympic Games doping ban | Leaks | High | 
| DCLeaks | US presidential elections 2016 | Leaks | High | 
| GUCCIFER 2.0 | US presidential elections 2016 | Leaks | High | 
| MacronLeaks | FR presidential elections | Leaks | High (Sandworm) | 
| OlympicDestroyer/Lazarus | Olympic Games doping ban, Pyeongchang. | Sabotage | Medium (Sandworm) | 
| RANA Leaks | Undetermined | Leaks | Low (overlaps with APT28 infrastructure & TTPs) | 

In its latest operations, APT28 seems to have gradually abandoned the creation of hacktivist avatars - which may have been judged too discriminating and heavy to implement - to give documents directly to journalists, influencers, or on several forums.

Following some operational security mistakes carried out by its operators and lawsuits engaged by occidental countries, a public attribution was carried out against this intrusion set. The attribution led to the public designation of several operators working within Units 26165 and 74455.

Following these lawsuits, the historical APT28 intrusion set (using its own tools, a discriminant infrastructure and carrying out false flags) seems to have mutated or disappeared. No more articles mentioning new attack campaigns associated with APT28 have been published since 2019.

In 2021, CLUSTER25 reported the use of a backdoor dubbed "[Skinny Boy](/intelligence/objects/malware--fa9a8c0d-1193-4bc1-8290-5c3a0dcbcc43)" which had potential links with APT28. However, the analysis of the backdoor and the context (mainly the associated infrastructure) done by SEKOIA.IO could not link it with high confidence to an APT28 resurgence.

The temporary end of the APT28 and Sandworm intrusion sets seem to have coincided with the resurgence of another Russian-speaking threat actor on the stage: [NOBELIUM](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--7dbe6e76-c59f-4dec-a7cf-c2a7e0210d16)/APT29, linked to the [SVR](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--de741e1a-061d-449f-a7d8-8d8aee0069b1). This resurgence of APT29 could indicate the Kremlin preference for other intelligence services to engage in cyber operations. This choice could be directly linked to the past errors of APT28 and Sandworm.

In 2022, Trellix attributed an attack to APT28 targeting Western Asia. Trellix found a new malware dubbed Graphite using Microsoft OneDrive as C2.

A report from Cluster25 researchers described a phishing technique used by fancybear since at least February 2022. The group uses a PowerShell Slide Show (.pps) document which execute a PowerShell code contained in its 'HyperLinks' metadata when the user opens it in presentation mode and move its mouse over it.

### New TTPs

Over the current **Russia-Ukraine war**, APT28 conducted **widespread phishing campaigns** to collect information to **provide political and military advantage**, and relied on opportunistic access through historical compromise to conduct **destructive cyber attacks**.

These recent attacks saw the emergence of new TTPs. APT28 today seems to prefer the use of disposable implants often developed in interpreted languages such as **Javascript**, **Powershell** or simple **bat scripts**, created specifically for each campaign. Their implants are not sophisticated at all and often linked to carrying out a single task such as creating a tunnel, recovering & exfiltrating passwords & co.

APT28 also seems to have switched from registered VPS and domains to **Mockbin services**, **TOR (for tunneling)** and **compromised network appliances** to create their operational infrastructure. This prevent easy correlation from a Threat Intelligence perspective.

objects.name: Ember BEAR
objects.description:
**EMBER BEAR** (aka Lorec53, UNC2589, UAC-0056) is a **Russia**-nexus intrusion set, active since at least 2020. Although no public attribution nor association is confirmed, EMBER BEAR shows consistent interests with [Russian military intelligence **GRU**](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--ca2f2a66-74c5-4c68-80a3-ec43478d8f50) : victimology (Ukrainian gouvernement and energy sector) and TTPs (the use of straitforward wipers against Ukraine)

On January 31, 2022, CERT-UA publicly attributed attack targeting an energy organization in Ukraine to a threat group they track as UAC-0056 also known as EMBER BEAR. In the following days, Unit42 and NSFOCUS shared more details on the intrusion set, its modus operandi and the previous campaigns attributed to the threat group. The UAC-0056 threat group is tracked as TA471 by Proofpoint, SaintBear by ThreatBook, Lorec53 by NSFOCUS, EMBER BEAR by CrowdStrike, and Nodaria by Symantec.

EMBER BEAR launched large-scale cyber espionage attacks against Eastern Europe targets (Ukraine, Georgia) and also against Iran. The publicly shared campaigns all seem to target government entities. According to NSFOCUS analysis:
>UAC-0056 (aka Lorec53) exposed a large number of Russian hacker characteristics in terms of attack tools, domain name registration information, asset location, etc., and its attack targets are also closely related to Russia's national interests. A study of UAC-0056's (aka Lorec53) development trajectory found that the organization was suspected of being employed by other high-level espionage organizations to obtain revenue by undertaking state-level espionage attacks or selling confidential government documents.
>UAC-0056 (aka Lorec53) has strong infiltration ability and changeable attack methods. It can organize large-scale and high-density phishing attacks. It is also good at learning from other organizations' social engineering technology and network resource management methods.

Beginning on April 6, 2021, just weeks after Russia began massing troops and military equipment
on the Ukrainian border, Ember Bear sent phishing emails to at least 1,966 unique recipients in Ukraine. 

The threat group is using OutSteel and SaintBot payloads, and they are also using different social engineering themes and infection chains to compromise systems. In several phishing campaignes, they used law enforcement theme based emails to lure the victim.

##### Toolset

UAC-0056 uses multiple custoù Golang implants since early 2022:
* Elephant Dropper: A dropper
* Elephant Downloader: A downloader
* SaintBot: A downloader
* OutSteel: Information stealer
* GrimPlant (aka Elephant Implant): Collects system information and maintains persistence
* GraphSteel (aka Elephant Client): Information stealer
* Graphiron: download & information stealer

An analysis of Threatray researchers pointed that the Graphiron and Elephant samples, both attributed to Ember Bear share a similar string decryption routine. In the samples, each string have their own hardcoded decryption routine. Even though these routine differ in terms of instructions, they are similar in terms of flow graph and semantic. These decryption routines are very specific to UAC-0056 and can be used to track their toolset.

Wiper :

objects.name: XENOTIME
objects.description:
XENOTIME, also known under the alias TEMP.Veles, is a Russia-nexus threat group that has targeted critical infrastructure active since at least early 2017. 

According to the US attributions (DOJ) and publications from cyber security editors (Dragos, Mandiant), XENOTIME is attributed to the State Research Center of the Russian Federation Central Scientific Research Institute of Chemistry and Mechanics ([TsNIIKhM](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--89634895-129b-4fba-a0ba-15fdd6d265cf)), an institute for research and developpment linked to Russia’s Ministry of Defence.

The group was exposed in late 2017 for the comproission of the Petro Rabigh joint venture petrochemical facility in Saudi Arabia leveragin  [TRITON](/intelligence/objects/malware--c101bc02-4075-426c-8c04-86ee6ed1954e), a malware framework designed to compromise an ICS system. Also referred to as TRISIS and HatMan, analysis indicated Triton was designed to enable an attacker to arbitrarily – and silently – modify an industrial component built by Triconex.

objects.name: Mallox ransomware crew
objects.description:
## Summary
Mallox is a ransomware group clamiming to encrypt victims' data and demanding a ransom not to leak it. Mallox distributes [the group’s namesake ransomware](/intelligence/objects/malware--ce7a3bf8-fae6-4ab1-97b8-51c55cea556e) known as Mallox, Fargo, TargetCompany etc. since at least June 2021.

So far, the group's internal organisation and its structure remain unclear to the public. On the Mallox Dark Web site, they and introduce four categories of "staff" people: `Admin`, `Support`, `Team` and `Panda`. They also [declare](https://www.suspectfile.com/interview-with-mallox-ransomware-group/) they are "a very small group of just a couple of people" ant that they operate from the "European region". It is likely composed by former members of other ransomware groups.

On their negociation panel with victims, Mallox operators declare to communicate in English only.
 
The ransom note contains instructions on how to contact the attackers. It urges victims to contact them via their TOR live chat (since at least October 2022) by logging in with a given personal ID, or to send it to a specific email address.

The ransom demands have been reported to range from $1000 to $60,000. SEKOIA.IO found that in the case of a Colombian-based victim, the ransom amount was reduced from $50,000 to $20,000 within a two-week period.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/6fdeffa07762bd4b9a4f4179ab438bf02f16cf41a58f86b5072410ea74262e1f.png)
Figure: Mallox' negociations with an unnamed victim (SEKOIA.IO, February 2023)

## Initial access
As of August 2023, the intrusion set is reported to mainly exploit vulnerable SQL Servers to gain access.

## Double Extortion
In the ransom notes from late 2021 - early 2022 seen by SEKOIA, the ransomware actors only asked for a ransom to decrypt victims' data.

Later in 2022, the group started to communicate about its double extortion tactic by threatening to publish the victims' stolen data initially on Twitter (starting from August 2022) and Telegram: "In case of non-payment of the ransom, your data may be published in the public domain".

Then beginning from November 2022, Mallox started to use a dedicated TOR site for double extortion. When a victim does not pay the ransom, the exfiltrated data is released on the group's public data leak site and on Twitter.

Sometimes the ransomware actors also threaten to contact the victims' partners ("we will let them know that you were the source of the data leak"). They also warn European victims that they are at risk of contravening the GDPR principles if the stolen data ends up being published on the group's websites.

**Mallox public data leak platforms**:
* `Mallox Data Leaks` aka `Mallox|Blog`: hxxp://wtyafjyhwqrgo4a45wdvvwhen3cx4euie73qvlhkhvlrexljoyuklaad[.]onion (embedded in ransom notes since November 2022, created on November 1st, 2022 or earlier)
* Mallox Telegram channel with data leaks: hxxps://t[.]me/mallox_leaks
* Mallox Twitter account with data leaks 1: hxxps://twitter[.]com/mallox_leaks (from August to mid-October 2022, currently suspended)
* Mallox Twitter account with data leaks 2: `hxxps://twitter[.]com/___Mallox___` (created in August 2022)

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/f28a2aa6d0ab1656b8be0b3d0ab7ca4eb5a0562fbb48399865e891fa00c70692.png)
Figure: Mallox DLS. Source: SEKOIA.IO, November 2022.

The group abuses the AnonFiles file-sharing service to upload and share exfiltrated data. 

**Mallox contact information**:
* Contact site for victims:
	* wtyafjyhwqrgo4a45wdvvwhen3cx4euie73qvlhkhvlrexljoyuklaad[.]onion/mallox/privateSignin 
	* hxxp://eghv5cpdsmuj5e6tpyjk5icgq642hqubildf6yrfnqlq3rmsqk2zanid[.]onion/contact (mentioned in late 2021 - early 2022 ransom notes, currently inactive)
	* hxxp://jnjorcburoayrwfrmnq3czngju76wdjyuyufqaep6joutvidohuh24ad[.]onion/contact (mentioned in early 2022 ransom notes, currently inactive)
	* hxxp://hye34tlszbt562z34d4k36eia2vq5tnhhd3mimrt5n5cdovbqnan3myd[.]onion/contact (mentioned early 2023 ransom notes)
* Email address:
	* mallox@]stealthypost.]net
	* newexploit@]tutanota.]com
	* mallox.resurrection@]onionmail.]org (starting from December 2022)
	* recohelper@]cock.]li (reserve email addres, "in case the first email will not reply in 24 hours")
	* mallox.israel@]mailfence.]com (seen in late 2021)
	* mallox@]tutanota.]com (seen in late 2021)
	* consultransom@]tutanota.]com (seen in early 2022)
	* consultransom@]protonmail.]com (seen in early 2022)
	* mawahelper@]tutanota.]com
	* mawahelper@]onionmail.]com

From the public samples that SEKOIA has collected, at least one victim initiated discussions and negociations with the ransomware group in February 2023.

## Victimology

Mallox ransomware targets entities of all sizes, worldwide - except some post-Soviet states. 

The victims identified by SEKOIA.IO in open source ranged from $5M to $782M in annual revenue.

According to information collected in late 2021-early 2023, victims of the ransomware included: an architectural firm in Germany, an American and a Japanese manufacturing companies, a Greek waste management company and several Indian companies, among others.

On the Mallox DLS, stolen data from 20 victims was released between 21 October 2022 and 24 March 2023.

objects.name: Killnet
objects.description:
**Killnet** is a Russia-aligned hacktivist group active since at least January 2022 as a Telegram messaging service selling distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack services. The group conduct DDoS, espionnage and hack-and-leaks operations on targets identified as anti-Russian. Killnet is particullary active in the context of the Russia-Ukraine war, and cooperates with other Russia-aligned hacktivist groups such as Zarya, NoNames057, Anonymous Russia, UserSec, and Anonymous Sudan. In February 2023, the Phoenix hacktivist group officially became part of Killnet. On April 2023, Killnet operators announced the group official name is now: **Russian Private Military hacker Company Killnet** (aka PMC Killnet or ЧВХК KILLNET). PMC Killnet aims at providing various services including destruction, production of UAVs, and means of tracking and suppression of drones, development of robotic systems, and software development, (the ‘destruction’ services include actions such as misinformation, impact on network infrastructure, and reputation killing). PMC Killnet additionally planned to update the list of its services, as it acquires specialists and expands partnerships in the CIS and abroad. According to their Telegram Channels (@killnet_channel and others such as @cyberwar_world, @Legion_Russia, @world_hacker_alliance), they are organised in 3 groups: * a "strike" group ("Ударная группа"), composed of so-called experts in penetration tests, phishing and DDOS; * a group composed of graphic designer; * a group in charge of media communication. The group also uses VKontakte to communicate.
On March 4th 2022, they declared working with **XakNet Team**.
Based on open-source reporting, Killnet released a video pledging support to Russia.
## TTPs ### DDOS
According to researchers from Forescout, Killnet’s attack vector of choice is Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS). They don’t use or develop custom tools and the tools they do use are not very advanced. The group leverage brute-forcing credentials on TCP ports 21 (FTP), 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS) and 22 (SSH).
Killnet claimed credit for carrying out a DDoS attack against a U.S. airport in March 2022 in response to U.S. equipment support for Ukraine.
### Data Leak
Killnet also claimed data leaks
## Victimology
Killnet is a group targeting Ukraine and Pro-Ukraine entities, as well as countries considered as "Anti-Russia". Reported targeted verticals include critical infrastructure, such as airports, banks, hospitals, intelligence services, transport systems, public services, and private organizations.
On June 2022, Killnet took responsibility for a days-long DDoS attack on Lithuanian’s public services, asserting the hit was a direct response to the blockade of goods imposed by Vilnius to the Russian territory of Kaliningrad.
In December 2022, Killnet claimed responsability for defacing an Australian building company.
## Organisation
Here is an overview of Killnet's organisation and ecosystem, as documented in open sources ( please see external ref)
![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/ba830f7136820c92b2c593e17dba36a1f3658e61a497933cabfc8b097336f81b.jpeg) Killnet and associates developed botnets and stressors, using open-source GitHub repositories. They also collaborate with DDoS-as-a-Service providers, and stressor developers to achieve their goals. Some of the key players are Mirai Botnet, Passion Botnet, Tesla-Botnet; built by RADIS, MistNet, SkyNet Botnet, and Godzilla-BotNet. Most of them are DDoS-as-a Service providers. Some of them are built and managed by KILLNET associates, like Tesla-Botnet. Passion Botnet and MistNet are directly associated with Killnet and engaged in DDoS campaigns. In April 2023, threat actors related to [Titan Stealer](/intelligence/objects/malware--c9918ab7-0845-4165-902b-2aa6e7b82d2d) integrated the KillNet galaxy. The announcement was made on the KillMilk (a structure within the KillNet galaxy) Telegram channel on 16 April 2023. On their own Telegram channel, Titan Stealer actors listed KillNet as a "DDoS partner". Since April 2023, Killnet is present on Twitter. The group also announced the formation of Black Skills, a Private Military Hacking Company on Telegram. For the time being, Sekoia.io analysts will continue tracking Kilmik's activities under the Killnet intrusion set.

objects.name: Turkish Cyber Army
objects.description:
Turkish Cyber Army, aka Devils Sec, is a turkish-speaking nationalist hacktivist group, allegelly issued from individuals linked with turkhackteam[.]org hacking forum. Based on communication from the group on Twitter, Turkish Cyber Army, as its current form, is active since early 2023.

Turkish Cyber Army presents itself as a turkish nationalist and islamic partisant, fighting against perceived ennemies (western and european states). 

On 12 June 2023, Turkish Cyber Army [declared](https://twitter.com/Devils_Sec/status/1668256129497874435) it solidarity with Russia and announced a cooperation with Russia-linked hacktivist group [Killnet](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--8addd30d-105c-47ba-ab3d-c6f10907b9eb) to target Ukrainian entities.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/5cba7c3422a73d69ffb8487f4f8ec86be2e0ab3fa5066a26e141f009cd1e8842.jpeg)

The individual Ghost Killer [present](https://twitter.com/thtghostkiller) himself as the leader of Turkish Cyber Army attack team.

objects.description:
NoName057(16) is an hacktivist nationalist group supporting Russia since at least March 2022. The group is primarily focused on DDoS operation targeting countries critical of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

The NoName057(16) main group main Telegram channel reached more than 43,000 subscribers as of June 2023.

The administrators of the group as well as the community are very active. They were notably observed conducting DDoS attacks using the [DDoSia malware](/intelligence/objects/malware--be000ef8-2a72-4ab0-ab41-3105e6998c88) against European, Ukrainian, and U.S. websites of government agencies, media, and private companies. Regularly, the group posts messages claiming successful attacks.

# Reported major DDoS attacks 

- March 2022 NoName DDoS attacks on Ukraine news and media websites Zaxid and Fakty UA
- December 2022 NoName disruption to Polish government website
- August 2022 NoName DDoS attacks on Latvia’s parliament
- Januray 2023 NoName DDoS attacks on Denmark financial sector 
- Januray 2023 NoName DDoS attacks on the 2023 Czech presidential election candidates’ websites
- March 2023 NoName DDoS attack on the French National Assembly
- April 2023 NoName DDoS attack on the Ukrainian Cabinet of Ministers
- May 2023 NoName DDoS attack on the French Senate

external_references.description: #StopRansomware: MedusaLocker
GlobeImposter Ransomware Being Distributed with MedusaLocker via RDP

objects.name: MedusaLocker operators
objects.description:
## Business

The MedusaLocker operators conducted its first attack in January 2020. The group is known to target large businesses, networks of organizations and companies. It first used the ThunderX ransomware and then renamed it Ranzy Locker after making some changes on the malware. 

From CISA analysis:

> MedusaLocker appears to operate as a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model based on the observed split of ransom payments. Typical RaaS models involve the ransomware developer and various affiliates that deploy the ransomware on victim systems. MedusaLocker ransomware payments appear to be consistently split between the affiliate, who receives 55 to 60 percent of the ransom; and the developer, who receives the remainder. 


## TTPs

Recent CISA advisory gives interesing information regarding the operator using [MedusaLocker](/intelligence/objects/malware--4eb87fe0-1f6a-4bbb-87b8-4ac5561e80de):

> MedusaLocker ransomware actors most often gain access to victim devices through vulnerable Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) configurations [T1133]. Actors also frequently use email phishing and spam email campaigns—directly attaching the ransomware to the email—as initial intrusion vectors [T1566].
> 
> MedusaLocker actors place a ransom note into every folder containing a file with the victim's encrypted data. The note outlines how to communicate with the MedusaLocker actors, typically providing victims one or more email address at which the actors can be reached. The size of MedusaLocker ransom demands appears to vary depending on the victim’s financial status as perceived by the actors. 
> 
Ahnlab asses the group also used [GlobeImposter](/intelligence/objects/malware--3cade096-ad69-40c1-8034-58fe56090ca0) instead of MedusaLocker in its attacks in early 2023. Also, not only do the MedusaLocker threat actors encrypted infected systems using their ransomware, but they also mine for coins by installing XMRig.

## Network infrastructure and contact information
Tor negociation site: `qd7pcafncosqfqu3ha6fcx4h6sr7tzwagzpcdcnytiw3b6varaeqv5yd.]onion`
Tor data leak site (named Ransomware Blog): `z6wkgghtoawog5noty5nxulmmt2zs7c3yvwr22v4czbffdoly2kl4uad.]onion`
Tox ID: `E9CD65687463F67F64937E961DD723DC82C79CB548375AAE8AA4A0698D356C5E7E157B22E8CD`

objects.name: APT33
objects.description:
**APT33** is an Iranian state-sponsored APT active since at least 2013. It has targeted organizations across multiple industries in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, with a **particular and continued focus** on the **aviation** and **energy sectors**. Due to the overlap with other Iranian APTs, its destructive capacities and shared victimology, SEKOIA.IO concurs to the public  **attribution to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps**.

The [**Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps**](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--dc788f6a-94ed-44f6-b935-fe8d9c923a2b) (IRCG) is an ideology-driven militia, branch of the Iranian Armed Forces, under the direct control of the supreme leader of the Islamic Republic. IRGC does not  answer to Iranian presidency. The Revolutionary Guards are in charge of protecting the iranian regime by  monitoring internal “deviant movements” and preventing foreign interference and coups. IRGC can be seen as an military elite corps with specific missions, including cyber capabilities to conduct espionage, sabotage and deception operations. 

Little information is available about Iran's internal cyber organization, which is known to cyber security researchers to be cloudy and evolutive. Due to the **use of proxy groups** and the **turnover of operators** from intelligence agencies to another, **Iranian intrusion sets often overlap TTPs, tools, infrastructures and modus operandi**. Thus attribution to Iranian intelligence agency, to proxy groups such as private firms or university institutes, or even the regroupment or differentiation of APTs has to be cautiously considered. 

Based on open-source publications, observed TTPs **overlap in between APT33 and APT35**, notably observed in the destructive campaign Shamoon (2012) could indicate operational coordination between these two intrusion sets.

Open-sources publications report that APT33 conducted operations with the support of different IRGC-aligned proxy groups notably including but not restricted to Nars Institute, Ashiyane Digital Security Team, Shahid Beheshti University (SBU), SBU’s Cyberspace Research Institute, Imam Hossein University and the Iranian Dark Coders Team.

*Dragos* differences **PARISITE** and **MAGNALLIUM**: "PARISITE does not appear to have an ICS-specific disruptive or destructive capability, demonstrating only initial access and enabling further operations for MAGNALLIUM."

**Iran attribution complexity**

Little information is available about Iran's internal cyber organization or doctrine, which is known to cyber security researchers to be cloudy and evolutive. Due to the use of proxy entities and the turnover of operators from one intelligence agency to another, Iranian intrusion sets often overlap as indicated by observed TTPs, tools, infrastructures and modus operandi over time. Thus, attribution to Iranian intelligence agency, to proxy entities such as private companies, universities or institutes, or even the grouping of or differentiation between APTs has to be cautiously considered.

**Iran cyber policy**

Iran does not present a public cyber strategy. However, the observed use of its capabilities shows a rational use of this tool, following three goals: to ensure the stability and maintenance of the regime by monitoring dissidents; to protect its territory focusing on intelligence gathering about adversary military intentions; and to promote and secure its regional ambitions by using cyber as a power-projection tool.

external_references.description: Play Ransomware's Attack Playbook Similar to that of Hive, Nokoyawa
Play Ransomware (.play) Support Topic
PlayCrypt Ransomware Group Wreaks Havoc in Campaign Against Managed Service Providers

objects.name: Play ransomware operators
objects.description:
## Resume
First observed in June 2022, the Play ransomware crew operates the [Play ransomware](/intelligence/objects/malware--33c47630-95c6-4670-92a3-bbbd8af40aa9) in double extortion attacks.

According to TrendMicro, the group uses many tactics that follow the playbook of both Hive and Nokoyawa ransomware, thus there is a high probability of affiliation between these ransomware families. TrendMicro also found evidence that points to a possible connection between Play ransomware and Quantum ransomware,

## TTPs and Tools
Here are the TTPs and tools used by the Play ransomware crew, based on TrendMicro report:
* **Initial Access**: gains initial access through valid accounts (VPN, exposed RDP, _etc._), using techniques such as remote monitoring and management (RMM) software, by compromising remote desktop software credentials and by exploiting FortiOS vulnerabilities CVE-2018-13379 and CVE-2020-12812. In August 2023, Adlumin Team reported on Play expanding its toolkit with new tools and exploits like ProxyNotShell, OWASSRF, and a Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution. 
* **Execution**: uses the Empire, SystemBC and Cobalt Strike post-exploitation frameworks, PsExec, creation of GPOs to deploy scheduled task from the AD and batch files. 
* **Privilege escalation**: uses Nekto/PriviCMD, Mimikatz and WinPEAS.
* **Persistence**: uses scheduled tasks and valid accounts. 
* **Defense Evasion**: uses tools such as Process Hacker, GMER, IOBit, and PowerTool to disable antimalware and monitoring solutions. The group uses .bat script and _wevtutil_ to remove indicators of its presence, such as logs in Windows Event Logs or malicious files. It disables Windows Defender protection capabilities through PowerShell or command prompt.
* **Credential Access**: uses Mimikatz to dump credentials, executed as module of Cobalt Strike and Empirer.
* **Discovery**: uses common ADFind, Nltest and Bloodhound tool for enumerating system and domain information.   
* **Lateral Movement**:
  * uses Cobalt Strike SMB beacon as a C&C beacon, a method of lateral movement, and a tool for downloading and executing files;
  * uses SystemBC, a SOCKS5 proxy, for backdooring mechanisms;
  * uses Empire for post-exploitation activity;
  * uses Mimikatz to dump credentials and gain domain administrator access on victim networks to conduct lateral movement.
* **Collection**: archives collected data using WinRAR
* **Exfiltration**: uses WinSCP, an SFTP client and FTP client for Microsoft Windows.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/689f0208a320a7e294db1348c5c1241650a31e7f5b52588f04eb3df19d8c2b2e.png)

## Custom malware
In April 2023, researchers at Symantec uncovered two custom tools in .NET developed by the Play ransomware group, namely `Grixba` and `VSS Copying Tool`. 
* **`Grixba`** is a network-scanning and information-stealing tool used to enumerate users and computers in a domain. 
* **`VSS Copying Tool`** enables Play ransomware to steal files from existing shadow volume copies even when those files are in use by applications.

## Network Infrastructure
* Play Data Leak Sites (DLS), since at least mid-November 2022:
	* `hxxp://mbrlkbtq5jonaqkurjwmxftytyn2ethqvbxfu4rgjbkkknndqwae6byd[.]onion` (`PLAY NEWS`)
	* `hxxp://k7kg3jqxang3wh7hnmaiokchk7qoebupfgoik6rha6mjpzwupwtj25yd[.]onion` (`PLAY NEWS`)
* Email addresses: in the ransom notes SEKOIA.IO analysed in open sources, the embedded email address followed this format: [random characters]@gmx[.]com or [random characters]@gmx[.]de
	* `evepmaminoeuy@gmx.de`
	* `inacpeiplan8p@gmx.de`
	* `teilightomemaucd@gmx.com`
	* `gyeceeidia7y@gmx.com`

objects.name: UNC2165
objects.description:
UNC2165 is a ransomware group identified by Mandiant in 2019. They overlap in their malware uses and server architecture with Evil Corp, which suggests either an affiliate status or a subgroup. They were mainly seen using Hades before switching to Lockbit.

While UNC2165 uses infections from FakeUpdates campaigns or stolen credentials, it has in-house capacities to expand, elevate privileges and deploy ransomware on the victim's network. First phase uses Cobalt Strike Beacon, in 2021 through Donut loader and then through Blister dropper. It escalates privileges using Kerberoasting and Mimikatz, while also searching for files with credentials and password managers. Its reconnaissance is made through Advanced Port Scanner, Lansweeper and managers available in the network. It then spreads through SSH and RDP and deploys its ransomware via custom scripts, making use of WMI and PsExec.

*"UNC” groups—or “uncategorized” groups—are raw attribution analysis made by FireEye. FireEye uses clusters of cyber intrusion activity which includes observable artifacts such as adversary infrastructure, tools, and tradecraft. When these clusters are not mature enough to earn a classification such as APT or FIN, FireEye uses the UNC monitor. The nature of this clusters is to grow, merge with, or break off from other clusters, potentially become combined under a TEMP name, such as TEMP.Warlock, and/or 'graduate' into fully defined groups, such as FIN11*

external_references.description: BRONZE PRESIDENT Targets Russian Speakers with Updated PlugX
Mustang Panda deploys a new wave of malware targeting Europe

objects.name: Mustang Panda
objects.description:
**Mustang Panda** is a [China](/intelligence/objects/location--01d5f74a-2417-4c8e-a799-4eda69ac64d0)-nexus Intrusion Set conducting cyber espionage campaigns since at least 2012.
While observed continuously targeting Mongolia, Mustang Panda also targets **non-governmental organizations** involved in diplomacy (including the Vatican, Myanmar, African and Asian countries), **think-tanks** (notably in the U.S.), **government** (Taiwan) as well as activists and ethnic minorities (Hong Kong, Tibet, Myanmar, Afghanistan), the **telecommunication vertical** in India, and **European countries**.
Mustang Panda mostly leverages lure documents mimicking those of the targeted country or organization, or even current world affairs applicable to that region, to conduct **spearphishing campaigns** to deploy malware, mostly **[PlugX aka. SOGU](/intelligence/objects/malware--1bd27a17-2c45-4864-bc7c-b2c77ddd17ac)**. Mustang Panda was also observed leveraging a unique infection chain using a series of redirections and fileless, malicious implementations of legitimate tools to gain access to the targeted systems. From September through November 2022, Mustang Panda regularly used an infection chain employing malicious shortcut (LNK) files, which trigger a dynamic-link library (DLL) search-order-hijacking execution chain to load consistently updated PlugX versions. In November 2022, the Intrusion Set was observed shifting from using archive files to using malicious optical disc image (ISO) files containing a simplified shortcut (LNK) file for delivery of **an updated PlugX payload dubbed [HODUR](/intelligence/objects/malware--f6a5abe3-37e9-4cbb-a41b-2364729570dd)**.
In recent activities, Mustang Panda was reported leveraging legitimate executables to side-load a malicious DLL, and a malicious DLL used to load RATs as part of its infection chain. In some campaigns, the Intrusion Set expanded its toolset to include reverse shells, [meterpreter](/intelligence/objects/tool--38d6ece7-4244-4dcd-a4fe-5c150c561b8b) and [Cobalt Strike](/intelligence/objects/malware--39304fbf-d301-47c3-ab06-7c96e5eb4c9b). In March 2022, Mustang Panda was reported targeting **Russian-speaking users** and **European entities**. It is not clear yet whether this unusual victimology was only temporary or could reflect a shift or an expansion of Mustang Panda strategic assignments.
Mustang Panda was reported leveraging [MQsTTang](/intelligence/objects/malware--b4506174-4b2e-43e3-bb9a-7a1b37398409) since at least January 2023, a bespoken backdoor using the MQTT protocol ( typically used for communication between IoT devices) for C&C communication. *Last Update : September 2023.*

objects.name: LockBit ransomware crew
objects.description:
## Overview

Formerly known as ABCD ransomware, LockBit is active since September 2019 and acts as an opportunistic, financially motivated intrusion set. LockBit is one of the most prolific ransomware groups in the cybercrime landscape, distributing ransomware as a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) and recruiting affiliates on popular underground forums.  LockBit 2.0 ransomware is one of the most active families in the wild and pretends to implement the fastest encryption algorithms using multithreading with I/O completion ports.

LockBit was one of the most active ransomware groups during the last two years and claimed the highest number of victims among all the for-profit ransomware groups in the first half of 2022 (439 victims announced on its extortion page, which represents 32,5% of all known ransomware attacks during S1 2022).

## LockBit’s continued evolution

Though the RaaS group **first advertised its affiliate program in January 2020**, its victim count rose exponentially mid-year 2021 onward when it **announced “LockBit 2.0**” - an updated version of the malicious program. A recruitment program was also launched for their new affiliates. This relaunch included redesigned Tor sites and numerous advanced features. The 2.0 version included automatic encryption of devices across Windows domains by abusing Active Directory (AD) group policies, prompting the group behind it to claim that it’s one of the fastest ransomware variants in the market today.

In August 2021, LockBit 2.0 began to advertise for insiders to establish initial access into potential victim networks, while promising a portion of the proceeds from a successful attack. 

LockBit 2.0 also developed a Linux-based malware which takes advantage of vulnerabilities within VMWare ESXi virtual machines. 

In March 2022, Lockbit ransomware group announced they intend to release **LockBit 3.0**. This new, upgraded version of the malware has already been spotted in malicious campaigns by May 2022. LockBit 3.0 affiliates get access to malware developed by the group, in return for a 20% share of the ransom payments.

In late 2022, the ransomware actors adopted the leaked Conti ransomware source code to create a custom **LockBit Green** variant.

## Internal Structure & Affiliates

LockBit representatives claim to be a large Netherlands-based group, with a strong affiliate network across the world, with “most of their developers and partners were born and grew up in the Soviet Union”.

Based on a report released by Prodaft in June 2021, at least 28 different affiliates were identified based on their management panel analysis.

LockBit does not allow the use of its ransomware in Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) countries as notably stated on their Data Leak Site (DLS). In an August 2021 interview, LockBit representatives mentioned: “For us, the unfriendly attitude of the West [towards Russia] is beneficial. It makes it possible to have such an aggressive business and feel calm operating from the CIS countries".

From Sekoia.io’s observations of the newly launched affiliate program (LockBit 3.0 aka LockBit Black), the LockBit group is looking for partners with varying levels of expertise and experience within the cybercrime business. It is highly likely that this is driven by LockBit to  widen and diversify its team and leveraged TTPs for LockBit 3.0 project, ultimately aiming at conducting more successful cybercriminal activities.
The main types of affiliates currently wanted are:
1. “cohesive and experienced teams of pentesters”;
2. Initial Access Brokers (IABs);
3. threat actors stealing data without encrypting it.

### Identified affiliates

1. Sekoia.io analyst published a [FLINT](/intelligence/objects/report--4788ad4e-aad9-469a-b170-028268b22d26) on 17 March 2023 exposing one of LockBit affiliate TTPs and infrastructure. This [LockBit Affiliate - Ransomware tool and exfiltration servers](/intelligence/objects/infrastructure--a1e942c7-a1ed-4e50-9a9d-2caed5f5d767) is kept up to date in Intelligence Center.
This affiliate uses  [Empire](/intelligence/objects/malware--43650dc8-980b-4b5f-9646-476cccbae2f7) OST as a post-exploitation tool and [ExMatter](/intelligence/objects/malware--ca72eb65-fc1e-48b5-9765-f0094b6ddbc5) for exfiltration.

2. On 16 May 2023, the U.S. Department of the Treasury designated Russian national Mikhail Pavlovich Matveev for his role in launching cyberattacks deploying ransomware variants such as LockBit, Hive, and Babuk. The FBI linked Mikhail Pavlovich Matveev to the [Wazawaka aka UNC1756](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--b8876b62-a791-4ebf-bc91-9e4dd3be12e2) persona. According to [Prodaft](https://25491742.fs1.hubspotusercontent-eu1.net/hubfs/25491742/WAZAWAKA_TLPCLEAR_Report.pdf), it operated under the `waza` nickname and was involved in LockBit attacks on 67 targets from May 2020 to March 2021.

3. Here is a list of LOckBit affiliates provided by Prodaft in December 2023:

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/336017d54b92d2bd782875cd76e37f56ff0d3aa9ae9a4e56ab6110122af3409e.png)

## Possible connections between LockBit and other ransomware groups 

To the best of our knowledge, there is no clear link of LockBit with any other known threat actor. However, Trend Micro noted in 2021 that LockBit operators initially worked with the Maze ransomware cartel. After Maze’s shutdown the LockBit group went on with its own leak site, which reportedly led to the development of its own ransomware. Two years later, the same source reported LockBit 2.0 similarities to Ryuk and Egregor ransomware.

In a June 2021 report, the Prodraft Threat Intelligence team reported some of the LockBit affiliates might also have worked for the Babuk and REvil ransomware groups.

The LockBit 3.0 version used since mid-2022 has some code similarities with samples related to the BlackMatter ransomware. It appears that the code in charge of loading its required functions for both LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter uses API hashing technique with the same hashing algorithm (ror13_add). The algorithm used to import the functions by their hashes is the same for LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter (ror13_add, but with different XOR keys), the hashing algorithm used for the module name is add_ror13. Moreover, both ransomware attempt to hide the main thread from the debugger.

These similarities would raise concerns about a possible link between the gangs behind LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter. Whether the link between the two groups is formal or casual, the code similarities between LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter are providing additional weight to the hypothesis that different ransomware groups, particularly those of Russian origin, are increasingly interconnected.

As LockBit Geen variant rely on the Conti source code, Prodaft asses that ex-Conti members might joined the LockBit operation after the Conti syndicate disbanded earlier in 2022.

## Modus operandi

The modus operandi observed during the attacks involving LockBit seems compatible with an financially motivated, opportunistic actor. Its operators adopted the same double extorsion method as other top-tier ransomware families with a dedicated leak site.

Like other ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operations, LockBit looks for affiliates to perform the intrusion and exfiltration on targets. Thus, the developers are in charge of the payment site and development and affiliates sign up to distribute the ransomware.

For initial access to a targeted corporate network, the LockBit gang recruits affiliates who perform the actual intrusion on targets, usually via valid remote desktop protocol (RDP) account credentials using common phishing and credentialing techniques. 

A network scanner takes stock of the network structure and identifies target domain controllers. Once in the domain controller, the ransomware creates new group policies and sends them to every device on the network. These policies disable Windows Defender, and distribute and execute the ransomware binary to each Windows machine.

This main ransomware module goes on to append the “.lockbit” suffix to every encrypted file. Then, it drops a ransom note into every encrypted directory threatening double extortion.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/160240bff35d03200be67beffcbd6fef27d11a2c278a48be486fd14eb5f3687c.png)
(Source : https://www.cynet.com/attack-techniques-hands-on/malware-evolution-analyzing-lockbit-2-0)

The final step for LockBit 2.0 is changing the victims’ desktop wallpapers into an advertising campaign recruitment ad to recruit new “affiliates” from inside the targeted companies themselves, which also includes instructions on how victims can pay the ransom. The average ransom amount is calculated to be roughly $85,000, as of June 2021. 

**Stealing data**

For data exfiltration, the ransomware comprises a built-in information-stealing trojan called StealBit, which is used for establishing access and automatically downloading files from an attacked company to LockBit’s updated blog. Before starting the encryption, LockBit affiliates use the StealBit trojan to steal files of their choice.

This is the second time a custom data exfiltration tool appears to have been developed by ransomware operators, following the earlier discovery of the Ryuk Stealer tool.

**Fast Encryption**

The strength of LockBit operators is, as the group claims, the fastest encryption speed among all ransomware available in the market currently. Moreover, the ransomware group claims it operates the world’s fastest stealer - StealBit.

LockBit actors often use publicly available file-sharing services such as anonfiles[.]com, privatlab[.]net, fex[.]net, transfer[.]sh, send.exploit[.]in, and sendspace[.]com. The data are saved in packages and uploaded to cloud services, such as MEGA.

According to Trend Micro, LockBit is only partially encrypting the files, as only 4 KB of data are encrypted per file. 

## The double extortion threat

LockBit attackers exfiltrate sensitive data and threaten to release it publicly if the ransom demand is not met. This tactic, employed by multiple ransomware groups that target enterprises, creates a dual pressure to pay the ransom– not just to unlock their systems but also to avoid public distribution of their stolen data

The group has also adopted other double extortion approaches, such as DDoS attacks.

## Attacker’s motivations

LockBit is an opportunistic, financially motivated threat group. Its ideology is displayed as anti-capitalist.

During Russia's war in Ukraine in early 2022, the LockBit group remained neutral (unlike other threat groups who took sides in the conflict ) : “We are not state-sponsored and we are not in politics at all”, due to members being from around the globe, as stated by LockBit on February 27, 2022.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/3dbd80251fe55e215c8347dc9f04995aac1cadc33fdf2b8f8caf6a399da85155.png)

## Victimology

Overall, the LockBit ransomware impacts organizations in almost every vertical. It is used for big game hunting (BGH) ransomware campaigns aimed at high-value targets. However, the most recent recruitment campaign launched by the group provides detailed instructions on which verticals should be avoided or not by affiliates.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/bd1842b3848487a8e9f1eb152297b7815471039daa3c485046b99d65ed879b68.png)
Overview of the LockBit group’s guidelines to its affiliates on the targeting of specific sectors, as announced while launching the new LockBit 3.0 affiliate program early July 2022


According to the statistics provided by SEKOIA.IO, a total of 761 victim companies were mentioned on the LockBit ransomware leak site between July 2021 (following the LockBit 2.0 release) and April 2022. Almost all of the victims are enterprise corporations. 

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/f288862bc3a9c7f6f2db720a170273a1bf1641e6c6fa9f9cee31ed81758af50a.png)

LockBit 2.0 targets organizations opportunistically. Closely examining the affected organizations, we concluded that most of them are in the manufacturing or the financial industry.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/f531aa6abdf4dab21bb271985f66fba80abc1110e787f77af747d4ad3c5ddd62.png)

## Dark Web activity

The LockBit group is known for offering LockBit as a ransomware as a service for a limited number of partners/affiliates on several Dark Web forums. In order to become an affiliate, one must have high skills, motivation, and good references who can verify the candidate. Affiliates are tasked with gaining initial access to the victim network, allowing LockBit 2.0 to conduct the rest of the attack.

The group' s members also benefit from their presence on Dark Web to promote their own exfiltration tool - StealBit, to collaborate with different IABs (Initial Access Brokers) and to regularly come up with inputs and statements on the latest developments in the cybercrime landscape.

The group's most prominent representative on cybercriminal forums is actually [LockBitSupp](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--63214ae7-8735-4c8c-a792-f5c3bb149c4c),  a very active Russian-speaking threat actor mostly operating on the XSS underground forum. "LockBitSupp" is steadily leveraging the increasing public interest in ransomware-related topics by offering interviews for both specialized and generalized media.

## Tools

| **Tool** |**Intended Use** |**Repurposed Use by LockBit Affiliates** |**MITRE ATT&CK ID** | 
| --- |--- |--- |--- |
| 7-zip |Compresses files into an archive. |Compresses data to avoid detection before exfiltration. |[T1562](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v13/techniques/T1562/001/) Impair Defenses | 
| AdFind |Searches Active Directory (AD) and gathers information. |Gathers AD information used to exploit a victim’s network, escalate privileges, and facilitate lateral movement. |[S0552](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v13/software/S0552/) AdFind | 
| Advanced Internet Protocol (IP) Scanner |Performs network scans and shows network devices. |Maps a victim’s network to identify potential access vectors. |[T1046](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v13/techniques/T1046/) Network Service Discovery | 
| Advanced Port Scanner |Performs network scans. |Finds open Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Data Protocol (UDP) ports for exploitation. |[T1046](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v13/techniques/T1046/) Network Service Discovery | 
| AdvancedRun |Allows software to be run with different settings. |Enables escalation of privileges by changing settings before running software. |[TA0004](https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v13/tactics/TA0004/) Privilege Escalation |
