objects.name: Sandworm
objects.description:
Sandworm is a well known Russian-speaking threat actor responsible for destabilization campaigns by doing sabotage and leaking operations against occidental interests. This intrusion set has been attributed by several intelligence agencies to Russia's **[General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU)](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--ca2f2a66-74c5-4c68-80a3-ec43478d8f50) Main Center for Special Technologies (GTsST) military unit 74455**. 

According to open sources, **Sandworm has been active since at least 2008 when they had attempted Distributed Denial of Service attacks (DDoS)** by using the first version of the [BackEnergy malware](/intelligence/objects/malware--52de4136-9d17-453a-aba5-0b6c681a671d) during the Russo-Georgian war. Following this first appearance on the international scene, Sandworm made the headlines in several international crises implicating Russia such as in Ukraine, following the Euromaidan crisis (2013) by doing several **sabotage campaigns against the Ukrainian government, media, transports and energy sector**. 

During the 2014-2022 cold confratation between Russian and Ukraine, Sandworm was also responsible for the creation of the [NotPetya worm](/intelligence/objects/malware--30a3a093-00e5-438f-a7ca-aa5d8ef92e03) that has been spread in hundreds of networks connected to Ukrainian entities. NotPetya, by mimicking ransomware, had sabotage capabilities **causing several billion dollars of damage for the infected companies**.

Sandworm is known to have been implicated in other crises such as the 2018 Winter Olympics destabilization attempt with the infamous [Olympic Destroyer](/intelligence/objects/malware--2fa4b91a-7684-494d-a0f6-71215867833e) malware or the Skripal case, by trying to **compromise physically the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons** and several laboratories working on this case (2018) via spear phishing campaigns. 

One of the most famous destabilization attempts done by the Sandworm intrusion set is the **French “Macron Leaks” (2017)** when the operators compromised several mailboxes of Macron staff members to leak their content to Wikileaks and on the /pol/ board of the (now defunct) 4Chan forum. This operation was a small part of a much wider spear phishing campaign targeting many sectors and individuals, related by Google TAG in 2020.

Even though Sandworm closely works with another GRU-linked intrusion set dubbed as [APT28](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--40479e35-a7ca-4c05-998d-2cf21ab751cc), their operators employ different TTPs. **Sandworm is more flexible and seems dedicated to special destabilization operations involving a smaller footprint in the targeted entities**. 

**Sandworm is largely active since the beginning of the Russia-Ukraine war**, conducting campaigns for **intelligence collection**, **multiple destructive network attacks**, contributing to **information operations**, and even, according to Google, using “hack-for-hire” services to secure initial access to some targets. 
Sandworn levareged multiple **straightforward** and **ready-to-use wipers** (HermeticWiper, AcidRain, Industroyer2, ZeroWipe, SwiftSlicer...) looking to [contribute](https://blog.sekoia.io/one-year-after-the-cyber-implications-of-the-russo-ukrainian-war/) to Russian intelligence to work faster, looking for more immediate effects  rather than complex and long-term planned destructive worms. 

# TTPs

One of the main characteristics of this intrusion set is to **use mostly open source tools for initial access ([Empire](/intelligence/objects/malware--43650dc8-980b-4b5f-9646-476cccbae2f7), [Meterpreter](/intelligence/objects/tool--38d6ece7-4244-4dcd-a4fe-5c150c561b8b), remote administration tools)** and **tailored and destructive malware to achieve their operations** such as [Industroyer](/intelligence/objects/malware--b0fab28c-b86a-4140-946e-0bd2a26e191c), [BadRabbit](/intelligence/objects/malware--461ca82d-640f-43b5-911a-97763e400899), NotPetya or even Olympic Destroyer. Sandworm intrusion set proven to master all of intrusion vectors from spear phishing to watering holes, frontal compromise and supply chain attacks. Moreover, they showed **their ability to develop their own modular implants for SOHO routers such as [VPN Filter](/intelligence/objects/malware--d9e9a85d-dbd9-471c-bb39-c70d122ada7f) and [Cyclops Blink](/intelligence/objects/malware--a76416d2-0551-4843-8c9f-fdf930a168e9) to constitute their own botnet**. 

Regarding its infrastructure, Sandworm is using compromised websites and VPS servers. **The use of domain names by this intrusion set is very rare** and they rely mostly on IPv4 addresses in their malware configuration. Historically, they also set up TOR relays on their C2s. **This use of TOR relays can be related to an attempt to prevent SIGINT interception**.

Since 2018, the Sandworm intrusion set operators have been subject to different lawsuits and public shaming from occidental authorities. In 2018, four sandworm operators were caught by the General Intelligence and Security Service of the Netherlands (AIVD) during a close access operation against the OPCW network. Following this raid, the identities of the GRU members and their attack methods were disclosed to the public.

In October 2020, the US Department of Justice indicted six other operators working for the Sandworm instruction set. These GRU Unit 74455 officers were indicted for several cyber operations such as NotPetya attack, the Macron Leaks, Olympic Destroyer or the operation against the OPCW network. Some of these attacks were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 26165, which is also dubbed as APT28. 

### 2022-2023 Russia-Ukraine war activity

Despite the public shaming and the indictments, and after a quiet period in 2021, Sandworm came back to the stage with the beginning of the Russo-Ukrainian War, with multiple compromise and sabotage operations targeting Ukrainian and occidental entities (mainly coutries supporting Kiev)

Sandworm was observed by many cybersecurity vendors using several kind of wipers impacting Ukraine entities.
* [Acid Rain wiper](/intelligence/objects/malware--0a2df090-4065-4a9d-a21e-84b6f0e9694d), used in the VIA-SAT operation impacting satellite communication
* [CaddyWiper](/intelligence/objects/malware--ab89b963-512f-41ca-be8b-3f77c0de651b) (used by APT28 as well), alongside Ar[guepatch d](/intelligence/objects/malware--b2016a76-1eaa-4367-808a-7cc2f4eb36cd)ropper
* [Prestige Ransomware](/intelligence/objects/malware--7114b03e-ec78-4820-9009-7af893930a6c), used as a wiper to target transportation and logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland.
* [AWFULSHRED](/intelligence/objects/malware--52eaa90b-aa36-4e09-bd6c-216d9b3ed463), used in a desctrutive operation impactive the Ukrainian Press Agency.
* [ZeroWipe](/intelligence/objects/malware--30b81fbb-0109-4439-93e8-1d6d8a4dd502), used in a destructive operation impactive the Ukrainian Press Agency.
* [SwiftSlicer](/intelligence/objects/malware--a04a6636-61b7-4390-8671-108937b74b8e)

objects.name: China
objects.description:
**China main strategic goals** * Preserving the **existence** and **legitimacy** of the Communist Party of China (**CPC**). * Protecting China’s **national interest security**, including its **territorial integrity** * Asserting **China’s power globally**, including in the cyber domain. Cyber is also used as a force multiplier in the land, air, sea and space domains.
These strategic interests are operationalized through: **Economic coercion** of neighbours and partners, notably through cyberespionage Leverage of a **wide array of instruments of national power**, including intelligence and cyber capabilities Influencing international **standards and policy making related to cyber**
Since at least **2006** China leveraged cyber capabilities to support these objectives. In 2013, Mandiant (FireEye) published their first report related to APT1 aka Comment Crew, one of the first documented China-nexus Intrusion Set. Since then, cyber threats aligning on China’s interests were continuously reported on, with observed **maturing in capabilities and Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs)**, as well as changes in its underlying organisation and doctrine. This aims at contouring the Chinese cyber threat for awareness and anticipation purposes. It must be noted that, as it is based on open source, sometimes contradictory information or intelligence gaps remain. Hence, it should be regarded as a snapshot of SEKOIA’s vision of the matter at hand at the time of writing.
*Last update: 20, July 2023.* _______________________________________________________________________ # Doctrine & Organisation Key drivers of Chinese offensive cyber doctrine revolve around territorial integrity and internal stability, and expansion and maintenance of regional and global influence. Cyber operations associated with China include industrial espionage to sustain economic objectives linked to self-reliance, intelligence collection pertaining to geopolitical and foreign policy disputes, and domestic operations to preserve the power of the Communist Party of China (CPC) with an emphasis on CPC narrative control, information monitoring and surveillance. China is actively reforming its national security apparatus including its civilian and military intelligence agencies which notably use cyber capabilities, both separately and jointly, to carry out cyber malicious activities. Most prominent agencies include the Ministry of State Security [MSS](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--d90d1397-46df-46ba-bcbe-93ddd9b053a0) and the People Liberation Army Strategic Support Force [PLASSF](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--70b6e373-0e99-46f1-8c80-b333a9896078), reorganised between 2017 and 2020. SEKOIA’s representation of the Chinese cyber offensive apparatus is as follow: ![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/44c4ef154813b5f4bb910825fccd78b5456f6d6f6e9d529affc21d07525e0863.png)
Several indictments report that both agencies use “proxies”, such as information and technology companies and universities to conduct their cyber operations. Since the 1920s, the CPC also developed a strategic concept known as “United Front”, a network of social, professional, political and academic organisations, to support the CPC’s interests and suspected to be involved in supporting Chinese intelligence activities, including cyber. This results in a vast number of stakeholders disconnecting China from malicious cyber operations, providing the State with *plausible deniability*, and further complexifying the threat landscape.
Since 2020, observed Chinese cyber espionage campaigns exhibited an increased risk tolerance in Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs) as well as increased activities’ tempo, echoing the country's wolf warrior diplomacy.
Domestically, China’s approach to cyberspace is driven by a technological imperative of self-reliance and ensuring long-term innovation-led growth, and a political drive of controlling the flow of information within cyberspace to safeguard regime legitimacy and social stability. The latter is notably reflected through China’s engagement in global cyber initiatives and its promotion of *cyber sovereignty*, a principle also emphasised by Russia, considered a key strategic partner by China.
# Targeting
Cyber operations associated with China include industrial espionage to sustain economic objectives linked to self-reliance, intelligence collection pertaining to geopolitical and foreign policy disputes, and domestic operations to preserve the power of the Communist Party of China (CPC) with an emphasis on CPC narrative control, information monitoring and surveillance. China-nexus Intrusion Sets notably conduct upstream collection campaigns through Managed Services Providers (MSP) and supply chain compromises to collect large amounts of data such as Personal Identifiable Information (PII). SEKOIA assess exfiltrated data is highly likely leveraged in follow-on cyber campaigns as well as HUMINT operations. Of note, information operations and surveillance campaigns are also achieved through legal means, such as the Cyber Security Law (CSL) enforced in 2017, and infrastructures such as the Great Firewall (GFW).
# Chinese reported cyber activities
**1. Cyber espionage**
* Industrial espionage Chinese cyber espionage operations present a continuous threat to intellectual property. Observed campaigns carried out by suspected China-nexus threat actors in the past notably targeted Western technologies such as high-tech, oil and gas, agriculture, manufacturing, biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, energy, aviation, aerospace, defence industrial bases, dual-use military application technologies, and telecommunications. While geographical distribution of China-nexus cyber campaigns victimology indicates a primary focus on Asia Pacific (APAC) region and North-America, China-nexus intrusion sets also targeted countries across the globe, including France, as well as countries and regions involved in Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Those are assessed to enable Chinese indigenous production and support Chinese industrial policies, such as the 14th Five-Year Plan (2021-2025). It is also assessed that strategic information collected through cyber espionage are likely [passed on to China champions](https://medium.com/cycraft/taiwan-high-tech-ecosystem-targeted-by-foreign-apt-group-5473d2ad8730) for commercial competition on international markets as well as gaining strategic know-how. * Strategic intelligence collection China continuously demonstrates efforts to increase its international influence and role as a major [regional power](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-malaysia-cyber-idUSKBN1L00X8), notably through territorial disputes and government programs and plans such as the BRI and Made in China 2025 (MIC2025). China’s political priority is to maintain territorial integrity, including over disputed land and maritime regions or *de facto* independent provinces. Examples of this driver include the regions of Hong Kong and Taiwan, disputed land ownership on the Sino-Indian border in Kashmir, and maritime territorial disputes in the South China Sea and East China Sea. * Surveillance Domestically, China-nexus Intrusion Sets carried out multiple surveillance campaigns against what is called “the Five poisons”, including Taiwan independence movement, the Tibetan Independence movement, the [Uygur ethnic group](https://blog.checkpoint.com/2021/05/27/minority-report-fake-human-rights-documents-and-websites-used-in-cyberattacks-targeting-uyghurs-a-turkic-ethnic-minority-in-china/), the Chinese democratic movement and the Falun Gong. Abroad, surveillance operations target the Chinese diaspora, including Chinese citizens, dissident groups, and members of China’s ethnic minority communities. **2. Military cyber activities** In relation to military cyber operations, PLA publications indicate that improving computer network exploitation and attack capabilities in order to degrade adversaries’ networks and information environments is seen as critical to winning future wars. Recent open source publications notably report on increased [targeting of Critical National Infrastructures by China-nexus Intrusion Sets](https://ics-cert.kaspersky.com/publications/attacks-on-industrial-control-systems-using-shadowpad/). It is assessed that the latest intelligence services reorganisation is likely to redistribute mandates, with the PLA focusing on operational environment preparedness, including cyber-enabled related activities. **3. Info Ops** [China information operations](https://www.irsem.fr/rapport.html) pose a high-volume threat globally. Initially focusing on regional targets and matters, it sensibly expanded to Western countries in 2020. Observed campaigns used a wide range of social media platforms and websites, and were two-folded – containing or censuring negative comments towards China and the CPC, and conveying negative narratives against European countries, the U.S or any country considered as hostile. Targeted audiences include the Chinese diaspora as well as international media, economy and politics stakeholders. It is almost certain that topics such as the Covid-19 pandemic or the exactions on the Uygur community led China to intensify its efforts in increasing its information operations. # China-nexus Intrusion Sets
Reflecting involved stakeholders in the Chinese cyber offensive apparatus, China-nexus Intrusion Set landscape is heterogeneous and opaquely state-linked, characterised by dynamic and evolving relationships between threat actors and state bodies across spectrums of direct government sponsorship and independent moonlighting activities. Additionally, it is suspected that these IS would resort to quartermasters (i.e. mutualized malware developers, possibly initial access brokers) which further blurs the lines. While this has a limited impact for detection, this hinders Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) efforts.
China-nexus Intrusion Sets leverage malware originating from China's hacking community, commodity malware, customised or repurposed tools, and zero-day software vulnerabilities. Open sources indicate that through steady investment in developing custom malware for privilege escalation, lateral movement and network reconnaissance, as well as improvements in command-and-control infrastructure, Chinese-linked intrusion sets departed from historically less advanced and "noisy" behaviour to becoming stealthier and more persistent. MSS-linked cyber espionage operators notably secured persistent access to victim organisations through compromises in third-party trusted supply chains and leveraging stealthy living-off-the-land initial infection vectors. Recently, China-nexus Intrusion Sets were observed leveraging ransomware in false flag cyberespionage campaigns.
Recently active China-nexus groups include APT4, APT10, APT25, APT27, APT31, APT40, APT41, Chromium, Naikon, and Mustang Panda.

objects.name: Russian Federation
objects.description:
**SUMMARY**

Russian intelligence is mostly divided into three main agencies that all have units that deploy cyber operations: The **[Main Directorate of the General Staff](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--ca2f2a66-74c5-4c68-80a3-ec43478d8f50)** (**GRU**) of the Armed Forces , the military intelligence agency; the **[Federal Security Service](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--9593a575-566d-4f58-96a0-45c95356d511)** (**FSB**) which is the continuation of ex-soviet KGB, in charge of internal security, counter-intelligence, counter-terrorism, and surveillance; the **[Foreign Intelligence Service](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--de741e1a-061d-449f-a7d8-8d8aee0069b1)** (**SVR**), Russia's external intelligence agency, focusing mainly on foreign politics and diplomacy.

There is a strong competition between those three agencies due to the overlap of their perimeters, where the FSB works as well on military intelligence and GRU being the actual main service for foreign intelligence to support foreign policy objectives.

Russian intelligence services have **extensive experience** in **conducting psychological and information operations** inherited from Soviet-era propaganda. Russian intelligence doctrine now includes **a new view of warfare** where the line between peace and conflict is blurred, and where **cyber operations** can be used as an **effective and relatively cheap tool** to undermine, subvert, and manipulate an adversary. 

Russian intelligence is well known for **interfering in elections of foreign countries** in order to manipulate domestic audiences and **undermine the faith in democratic systems**. Instead of seeking a particular outcome (as it was assumed for the 2016 US presidential elections), the goal for Russian information operations is more on causing chaos and weakening the domestic legitimacy of an adversary’s government.

If all those **three agencies** conduct cyber operations to **collect intelligence** with a high technical level, **slightly different modus operandi can be noted**. GRU operations include **destructive** or “hack-and-leak” operations when the FSB is also a **point of contact** for Russian-aligned cybercrime groups. The SVR is known to operate with a high degree of discretion, seeking to gain and retain access and **trying to avoid detection**. 

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/b9645ad13412fcb8701240fda9844c6ef9f99bdbebd8486d0555fb9b1b36c92f.png)

**HISTORY**

Russian intelligence services have a complex relationship with the soviet era KGB, which is important to know in order to understand the roles, objectives and means of the offensive cyber operations conducted by Moscow.

After the fall of the Soviet Union, Boris Eltsine, the first president of the Russian Federation, wanted to reform the intelligence services, principally the KGB which was the symbol of the ex-totalitarian regime's dirty work. Especially after the failed 1991 Soviet coup attempt, conducted by hardliner communist including the head of KGB Vladimir Krioutchkov, Eltsine wanted to gain more control over this institution.

In order to simulate concurrency and efficiency among new intelligence agencies, but also to have a better democratic control over them, **Boris Eltsine decided to split the KGB**, in two agencies, the FSB and the SVR. The KGB’s first directorate for foreign intelligence (PGU) functions were transferred to the SVR in 1991, and the second directorate (VGU), in charge of counter-espionage, was transferred to the FSB.

Even if both agencies are issued from KGB, in terms of human resources the **FSB can be considered as the true heir of the soviet agency** (~150,000 employees work for the FSB, 15,000 for the SVR). Moreover, the FSB kept the ancient headquarters of the KGB in Loubianka place in Moscow. The FSB was also charged with the protection of Russian economic interests in the 90s.

In the meanwhile, **Elstine preserved the name, budget and organization of the GRU**. To him, the institution was more legitimate than the KGB, less steeped by communist ideology and barely known for human right violations. The GRU intelligence agency was supposed to report only to the Ministry of Defence, and thus was presumed to be more pragmatic than political. Many foreign intelligence positions left vacant were given to GRU military officers.

objects.name: North Korea
objects.description:
North Korea (aka DPRK for Democratic People's Republic of Korea) was observed conducting cyber offensive activities **since at least 2004**. Called the "secret war" by Pyongyang, there is no open source document pertaining to North Korea cyber doctrine to date. DPRK offensive cyber doctrine, associated with the development of a ballistic, nuclear, and bacteriological arsenal, is a force multiplier, notably in subverting international sanctions and funding Pyongyang’s economy.

DPRK cyber malicious activities include **cyberespionage** operations, **lucrative** campaigns and **destructive** and **disruptive** attacks. Of note, no destructive attack was associated to DPRK since 2015, and the last disruptive attack attributed to Pyongyang dates back from 2017 (WannaCry).

DPRK strategic objectives pertain to the **survival of the North Korean state**, as well as **maintaining its position within the international system** as a “small great power.” To that purpose, DPRK-associated Intrusion Sets were seen conducting cyberespionage campaigns, notably against defense and security-related entities, entities and individuals involved in nuclear policy amd military matters, and international organisations, to collect strategic and military intelligence. Lucrative campaigns associated to the DPRK were observed targeting banks, cryptoassets users and platforms (including cryptocurrency exchange and mixers) as well as the financial technology sector. Additional targets of interest to the DPRK are Korean Peninsula-related NGOs and enties.

DPRK malicious cyber activities involve multiple state organisations, including the Ministry of State Security ( MSS aka Bowibu) and the Reconnaissance General Bureau (known as RGB). Associated DPRK Intrusion Sets include [Lazarus](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--2c618d0f-c909-4400-9783-668ce297124f), [Bluenoroff](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--a71b9f4f-4ace-4d82-bd84-fb9599e57a26), [Andariel](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--f410b643-65c3-47e7-8cf9-76d06c7f5775), [Reaper](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--234dd351-8674-4553-934c-76cbf5efc0cb), and [Kimsuky](intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--baf76692-a00e-4c2a-85fd-da17438b08a7).

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/a105a1bb1b1b622c83f891bd44fc2a4c37d539b95fea4f6a57211bc3f0437df6.png)

objects.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of
objects.description:
**SUMMARY**

The Islamic Republic of Iran presents a **cyber offensive capability** that is operated by two main intelligence agencies, the [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--dc788f6a-94ed-44f6-b935-fe8d9c923a2b) (**IRCG**) and [Ministry of Intelligence](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--ba4d7339-0209-4380-8b50-9ef7935327f0) (**MOIS**) which use their own operatives or appeal to **proxy groups** under their coordination. 

Contrary to other states, **Iran does not present a public cyber strategy**. However, the observed use of its capabilities shows a rational use of this tool, following **three goals**. 

First in domestic policy, Iran uses cyber operations to ensure the **stability** and **maintenance of the regime** by monitoring political dissidents, journalists and activists seen as vectors of foreign influence. Secondly, Tehran operates cyber groups to **protect national territory** perceived as militarily threatened by enemies (USA, Israel, Saudi Arabia, Russia and some European countries). Thus, cyber operations focus on **espionage** and **intelligence gathering about adversary intentions**. And last, in foreign policy, Iran operates cyber operations as a **power-projection tool** to promote and secure its regional ambitions (Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Israel, Yemen). 

Since 2018, Iran-linked APTs are considered a **serious threat**, reaching **operational and technical maturity**. Iran uses its cyber capabilities to target mainly its regional and strategic adversaries such as Saudi Arabia, Israel, the UAE, the US but doesn’t seem to directly target French interests as priority.

The **main difference** between **IRGC** and **MOIS** is their staff recruitment - IRGC recruits more ideology-driven staff than MOIS - and their **direct affiliation into the iranian regime**. IRGC is under the direct control of the Supreme Leader when MOIS answers to the Presidency. From 2013 to 2021, the election and mandate of moderate president Rouhani made MOIS cyber operations more covert and less destructive, in order to comply with its appeasement policy with the West. At the same time IRGC leaders were opposed to such a strategy and were deploying aggressive cyber operations towards perceived threats. Since the **election of conservative Raissi** as president in 2021, the Supreme Leader and the presidency share the same strategy. SEKOIA assesses that **MOIS** and **IRGC APTs** will thus **converge** on the **same** **operational use** of cyber offensive capabilities.

In Iran, academic institutions, such as **Imam Hossein University** and **Shadid Beheshti University** are assisting the Iranian cyber program by enhancing the technical capabilities of intelligence operators and by conducting operations as proxy. 

**Private companies** (Mabna Institute, Rana Company, …) are also often **contracted** **by intelligence** or military entities to conduct cyber operations, sometimes with the technical collaboration or with a shared attack infrastructure furnished by the contractors. This proxy use complicates efforts to assess attribution.

**IRAN CYBER THREAT EVOLUTION**

Iranian cyber threat is known to evolve quickly, as much for its technical and operational capabilities. In 2020, open-source publications showed that Iran-linked APT are now deploying more and more ransomware operations, using cybercrime techniques in order to both finance private proxy groups and state treasury, disrupt their target, and complicate efforts to assess attribution.

Iran APTs are also more patient and persistent while engaging with their targets, but still continue to employ aggressive brute force attacks on some targets.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/4c684ce40e7606610dd2e62d72135905d5056a7a88f1285dced857f004fb3aad.png)

**HISTORY**

For a better comprehension and understanding of Iranian cyber operations, an **historical approach** is important to assess how cyber was fully integrated into state services.

Iran's cyberspace approach has evolved since **2010** and the alleged **origin of cyber use** for Iranian state. Formerly used as an internal tool for information control and regime stability, it has evolved to an open use to conduct espionage, destructives attacks and lucrative operations on foreign targets.

The origin of Iranian cyber operations as a power tool has **two origins** : the **2009 Green Movement** where civilians protested against the reelection of Ahmadinedjad, former conservative president ; and the **discovery of 2010 STUXNET**, allegedly developed by US and Israeli services to damage nuclear centrifuge machines. Iranian leaders then understood the necessity of domestic internet and social media control in order to maintain the stability of the regime, and the **potential for cyber operations**, as a target and as an attacker. Iran created a Supreme Council of Cyberspace shortly after, in 2012.

In august 2012, Iran has put its new cyber policy into action by deploying its **first wiper** malware dubbed "**Shamoon**" against Saudi Arabia’s oil company **Aramco**, causing significant industrial damage.

Since 2012, Iran cyber capabilities have **increased every year** in **technical** and **operational skills**. Tehran operates its cyber operations with an asymmetrical approach. Rather than trying to reach highly technical attacks, Iran conducts DDoS, defacement, deception, sabotage and espionage operations, through intermediate technical sophistication. Iran's asymmetrical tactic **targets** in particular **industrial** and **financial entities** to maximize economic damage and media coverage. 

Since 2020, according to US intelligence services, Iran has the ability to conduct **attacks on critical infrastructure**, as well as to conduct influence and espionage activities.

objects.name: OlympicDestroyer
objects.description:
Olympic Destroyer is a worm and a wiper developed and operated by the Sandworm threat actor during the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Olympic Destroyer embeds several modules encrypted in AES in its PE resources such as:

* Windows Account Password Stealer
* A Destroyer / Wiper
* Copy of PsExec
* Browser Password Stealer
* A Loader

Two main variants of Olympic Destroyer have been seen ITW. The first version is a flawed version which spreads a OD binary which hasn't been patched with the stolen credentials, therefore, the impact is limited. The second variant isn’t flawed. It spread the patched versions of Olympic Destroyer containing stolen credentials, thus allowing better worming capabilities.

objects.name: NotPetya
objects.description:
NotPetya is a worm and wiper authored by the Sandworm intrusion set. This piece of malware was used in a worldwide attack that occurred on June 27, 2017. This attack started thanks to a malicious software update against the MeDoc Ukrainian software customers and a watering hole on - at least - one Ukrainian news website. 

This worm had the particularity to embed three different vectors to spread inside the compromised networks such as using PSExec, WMI and via the EternalBlue - previously leaked - NSA exploit targeting the MS17-010. NotPetya also embedded some snippets from the Mimikatz project in its resource section to grab passwords from infected computers' lsass memory. 

Once executed, NotPetya disables the events logging, infects the Master Boot Record to print a decoy message pretending that is a ransomware and implements a flawed file system encryption component using AES128-CBC and RSA, preventing the victim from recovering the encrypted files. Then the worm restart the compromised workstation by creating a scheduled task which executes the shutdown executable one hour after the initial infection or use the NtRaiseHardError native API call to reboot the machine.

objects.name: ZeroWipe
objects.description: ZeroWipe is, according to CERT-UA, a wiper used by Russia-nexus [Sandworm](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--f29bd8cc-1cea-497c-ac3f-8d590b95c9d6) APT and observed by the Ukrainian as part of a destructive operation targeting the Ukrainian National Information Agency "**Ukrinform**".

external_references.description: Play Ransomware's Attack Playbook Similar to that of Hive, Nokoyawa
PLAY Ransomware
Ransomware Spotlight: Play

objects.name: Play ransomware
objects.description:
## Resume
Initially reported in June 2022 on a security forum by alleged victims, the first public case of PLAY Ransomware was announced when a journalist uncovered that Argentina’s Judiciary of Córdoba was victimized.

Play is a heavily obfuscated ransomware which appends the file extension ".play" to encrypted files and drops the ransom note into the drive folder only.

As reported in September 2022 by TrendMicro, the [Play operators](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--d82d2e1e-791b-4aef-bfb9-4f54b6735de5) use many tactics that follow the playbook of both Hive and Nokoyawa ransomware, thus there is a high probability of affiliation between these ransomware families. TrendMicro also found evidence that points to a possible connection between Play ransomware and Quantum ransomware.

## Signs of infection
**Ransom note**: `ReadMe.txt`
**Encrypted files extension** : `.play`

## Analysis
The Play ransomware implements multiple capabilities, including:
* Anti-analysis;
* Encryption;
* DLL injfection;
* Execution on network.

The Play ransomware can run with or withouth command-line arguments.

### Anti-analysis Features
According to Chuongdong in-depth analysis, the Play ransomware :
* is able to bypass most static analysis through IDA’s disassembly and decompilation;
* obfuscates its code by littering its code with random moving instructions;
* implements API name hashing (the API resolving function takes in a target hash and a DLL address);
* encrypts its strings.

### Encryption Routine
Before iterating through all drives to encrypt, Play enumerates all volumes on the victim’s system.

The ransomware uses a depth-first traversal algorithm to iterate through the file system.

If a file extension matches one of the following list, it doesn't encrypt the file: `.exe, .dll, .lnk, .sys, readme.txt, bootmgr, .msi, .PLAY, ReadMe.txt`. It does not encrypt file if its size is less than 6.

The Play ransomware avoids encrypting the "WIndows" repository.

The malware uses the generic RSA-AES hybrid-cryptosystem to encrypt files.

Bad Rabbit: Not‑Petya is back with improved ransomware

objects.name: Bad Rabbit
objects.description:
BadRabbit is a destructive worm used by the Russian intrusion set Sandworm in October 2017, after the NotPetya devastating attack. This fake ransomware was used to hit major networks in Ukraine, but spread mainly across Russian networks. 

BadRabbit was distributed via watering holes. Several popular Ukrainian news websites were compromised to include a malicious piece of Javascript pushing the victim to download a fake update for Flash Player, which was, in fact, the BadRabbit dropper.

Bad Rabbit has the ability to spread via SMB. The malware scans internal networks and launches Mimikatz on the compromised computers to harvest more network credentials. If credentials are found, the malware copies and executes itself using SCManager and rundll.exe.

Bad Rabbit is an improved version of NotPetya, the bug in file encryption is corrected. The encryption uses DiskCryptor, an open-source full drive encryption tool. AES-128-CBC keys are used and protected by a hardcoded RSA 2048 public key.

objects.name: MedusaLocker
objects.description:
A Windows ransomware that will run certain tasks to prepare the target system for the encryption of files. MedusaLocker avoids executable files, probably to avoid rendering the targeted system unusable for paying the ransom. It uses a combination of AES and RSA-2048, and reportedly appends extensions such as .encrypted, .bomber, .boroff, .breakingbad, .locker16, .newlock, .nlocker, and .skynet.

CISA notice provide information regarding some behavior of the MedusaLocker:

* Restarts the LanmanWorkstation service, which allows registry edits to take effect. 
* Kills the processes of well-known security, accounting, and forensic software. 
* Restarts the machine in safe mode to avoid detection by security software [T1562.009].
* Encrypts victim files with the AES-256 encryption algorithm; the resulting key is then encrypted with an RSA-2048 public key [T1486]. 
* Runs every 60 seconds, encrypting all files except those critical to the functionality of the victim’s machine and those that have the designated encrypted file extension. 
* Establishes persistence by copying an executable (svhost.exe or svhostt.exe) to the %APPDATA%\Roaming directory and scheduling a task to run the ransomware every 15 minutes. 
* Attempts to prevent standard recovery techniques by deleting local backups, disabling startup recovery options, and deleting shadow copies [T1490].

Updated BlackEnergy Trojan Grows More Powerful

objects.name: BlackEnergy
objects.description:
BlackEnergy is a malware that was created by a Russian developer named Dmytro Oleksiuk and also known as Cr4sh. The first version of Black Energy was a pretty straightforward DDoS bot with only simple commands. According to a blogpost from Cr4sh, he sold the source code of Black Energy on underground forums for $700 in 2007. In mid-2008 the Sandworm intrusion set made significant modifications to the original version, creating a new modular version of the bot called by the industry “Black Energy 2”.

Unlike the first version, the second version of BlackEnergy was more complex, obfuscated and used process-injection techniques. It allowed the operators to retrieve and execute plugins from the C2 servers. Several plugins mostly related to DDoS actions were developed. In addition to plugins, backenergy can act also as a standalone backdoor with a small set of standard commands such as:

* `rexec` download and execute a remote file;
* `lexec` – execute a local file on the infected computer;
* `die` – terminate bot execution;
* `upd` – update the bot;
* `setfreq` – set the beaconing frequency;
* `http` – send an HTTP request to the specified web page.


It's in 2014 that specific plugins, developed to interact with ICS systems or to destroy computers, were developed and used against occidental and Ukrainian targets. The use of BackEnergy by Sandworm gave the name of BackEnergy to this intrusion set by the editor. Finally, several plugins were developed by the sandworm intrusion set such as (List from Wikipedia) :
 
* fs.dll — File system operations
* si.dll — System information, “BlackEnergy Lite”
* jn.dll — Parasitic infector
* ki.dll — Keylogger
* ps.dll — Password stealer
* ss.dll — Screenshots
* vs.dll — Network discovery, remote execution
* tv.dll — Team viewer
* rd.dll — Simple pseudo “remote desktop”
* up.dll — Update malware
* dc.dll — List Windows accounts
* bs.dll — Query system hardware, BIOS, and Windows info
* dstr.dll — Destroy system
* scan.dll — Network scan

Sandworm seems to have stopped the use of BackEnergy during its campaign since at least 2015. BackEnergy was replaced by several backdoor and tailored implants for specific tasks such as Industroyer or Kill Disk.

objects.name: Lumma
objects.description:
## Resume

First seen in August 2022, Lumma is an information stealer written in C using WinApi functions. In late 2022 a new version (LummaC2) was released on underground forums. Lumma is sold and distributed as a Malware-as-a-Service. According to the [threat actor advertising the LummaC2 on cybercrime forums](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--af95847c-0de9-4f76-8007-986f0cc56a70), it is forbidden the stealer is not distrbuted in Russia and Belarus.

Lumma's capabilities are those of a classic stealer, with a focus on cryptocurrency wallets. Here are the main capabilities:
* Targeting of browsers (to steal passwords, cookies, autofills and credit cards);
* Targeting of Desktop cryptocurrency wallets and extension for cryptocurrency wallets (Exodus, Binance, Electrum, Electrum LTC, Etherum, Jaxx, ElectronCash);
* Listing running processes.

As Mars Stealer and Vidar do, Lumma downloads legitimate third-party libraries for data collection into compromised hosts (`sqlite3.dll`, `nss3.dll`, `mozglue.dll`, `freebl3.dll` and `softokn3.dll`).

Lumma is sold as a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) by LummaC on Russian-speaking underground forums (such as XSS and RAMP) and Telegram. 
* LummaC: hxxps://xssforumv3isucukbxhdhwz67hoa5e2voakcfkuieq4ch257vsburuid.]onion/threads/71739/
* LummaC2: hxxps://xssforumv3isucukbxhdhwz67hoa5e2voakcfkuieq4ch257vsburuid.]onion/threads/78553/
* LummaC2: hxxp://rampjcdlqvgkoz5oywutpo6ggl7g6tvddysustfl6qzhr5osr24xxqqd.]onion/threads/lummac2-universal-stealer-a-malware-for-professionals.1099/


One of its alleged developpers is [c0d3r_0f_shr0d13ng3r](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--e99c4590-751b-4b09-ab2d-3c06547806d9), a possible contributor for the LummaC project, advertised by the [Shamel](/intelligence/objects/threat-actor--af95847c-0de9-4f76-8007-986f0cc56a70) threat actor.

## Analysis

_The following technical analysis is based on the sample `7873dddec4a46e7ad104de9b6bd68f590575b7680a1d20b9fe1329d1ad95348f`, first seen in the wild on August 11, 2022, which would correspond to a version under development._

### Step-by-step execution

Here is an overview of the step-by-step execution of the Lumma stealer:
1. The malware sends the string `ct_start` using an HTTP POST request (URI /windbg) to its C2 server, probably to initiate the communication.
2. It then sends the string `chr_start` using an HTTP POST request (URI /windbg) to its C2 server, before downloading the legitimate third-party DLL `sqlite3.dll` by sending an HTTP GET request to `/lib/sqlite3.dll`.
3. Lumma then sends the string `moz_start` using an HTTP POST request (URI /windbg) to its C2 server, before downloading the other legitimate third-party DLLs `nss3.dll`, `mozglue.dll`, `freebl3.dll` and `softokn3.dll`.
4. Once DDLs are downloaded, the malware sends the string `grb_start` using an HTTP POST request (URI /windbg) to its C2 server to indicate it will start to grab information.
5. It then collects data from web browsers and Desktop crypto wallets, lists the running processes on the infected host.
6. Collected data is stored in `ProgramData\config.txt` and then compressed in a zip file named `winrarupd.zip`.
7. It sends the string `upl_start` to its C2 server, again HTTP POST request on /windb, to indicate it will start to upload data.
8. The malware then exfiltrates the archive to the C2 server using a HTTP POST request (URI /winsock).

The malware updated its capabilities since version 4.0:
- **Control Flow Flattening** (CFF) obfuscation implemented
- New **Anti-Sandbox** technique to delay detonation of the sample until **human mouse** activity is detected.
-  **Strings** are now **XOR** obfuscated instead of simply modified by adding junk strings in the middle.
- Supports dynamic configuration files retrieved from the C2, where the configuration is **Base64** encoded and **XORed** with the first 32 bytes of the configuration file.

The developer enforces threat actors to use a crypter for their builds.

Side note about the CFF: Lumma changed it CFF technique regulary in the different versions. The control flow is modified by a sort of large state machine where in some version the state are constante and in newer version they are pushed on the stack.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/f136385fdd74140122880e20a56a6d4ed247151ba8c2ea5b78ccc94feda4c244.png)

### Lumma administration panel

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/d574da684eb4efaf50a04a02b3b5ce73968666352870d850031fef586d1b8022.png)

## Tracking the C2 infrastructure

_The following content is from September 2023 and is taken from the report [FLINT 2023-033 - Tracking the C2 infrastructures of the prevalent infostealer families](/intelligence/objects/report--1b3f4bf9-e607-48ca-a7a6-f0abb972aba2). The heuristics mentioned may change over time._

### URL-based heuristic

Lumma samples communicate with their C2 domains using HTTP to:
* Register on its C2 server using a GET request to the root “/”;
* Retrieve its encrypted configuration from its C2 server using a POST request to “/c2conf”;
* Exfiltrate harvested data using POST requests to “/c2sock”.

A basic heuristic based on the URL pattern stems from the Lumma C2 communications. Sekoia.io analysts use a query similar to the following on urlscan:
* [`filename:( "c2sock" OR "c2conf") page.status:200`](https://urlscan.io/search/#filename%3A(%20%22c2sock%22%20OR%20%22c2conf%22)%20page.status%3A200)

### Cloudflare DNS records

Lumma’s C2 domains are hosted by Cloudflare since the end of June 2023. By correlating the DNS NS records, the SSL issuers, registrar information and the top-level domains (TLDs), we retrieved over 200 domains associated with Lumma C2 servers.

For all domains, URLs to the root return a characteristic HTML web page containing Russian text. By pivoting on the HTML content, we found the possible C2 servers using the following query on Shodan. They are highly likely behind the Cloudflare-protected domains:

* [`http.title:"Есенин" http.html:"Ты меня не любишь"`](https://beta.shodan.io/search?query=http.title%3A%22%D0%95%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%22+http.html%3A%22%D0%A2%D1%8B+%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8F+%D0%BD%D0%B5+%D0%BB%D1%8E%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%8C%22)

objects.name: Hades
objects.description:
Hades ransomware has been considered as a variant of WastedLocker by some [security companies](https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/hades-ransomware-successor-to-indrik-spiders-wastedlocker/).

But for SecureWorks, it is a distinct one with the following characteristics:

> Some Hades samples analyzed by CTU researchers use the “ClassicStartMenu.exe” filename and have December 2020 creation dates, which coincides with the first reports of the ransomware. The Hades ransomware executable copies itself into a random %AppData% folder and then executes via the “/go” argument. It checks the compromised environment for virtualization and debugging tools. Like many other ransomware families, Hades deletes volume shadow copies using the “vssadmin.exe Delete Shadows /All /Quiet” command. It also uses a distinctive self-delete command with an unusual inclusion of a waitfor command: cmd /c waitfor /t 10 pause /d y & del "<ransomware file path>" & rd "<ransomware folder>".

external_references.description: New “Prestige” ransomware impacts organizations in Ukraine and Poland

objects.name: Prestige
objects.description:
### Summary
Prestige is a ransomware identified by the Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) in October 2022.

Prestige targeted organizations in the transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland since October 11, 2022, using a previously unidentified ransomware payload. The Prestige ransomware had not been observed by Microsoft prior to this deployment on this date. MSTIC has not yet linked this ransomware campaign to a known threat group.

This ransomware labels itself in its ransom note as “Prestige ranusomeware”.

### Malware analysis
The “Prestige” ransomware requires administrative privileges to run. Like many ransomware payloads, it attempts to stop the MSSQL Windows service to ensure successful encryption using the following command (the strings “C:\Windows\System32\net.exe stop” and “MSSQLSERVER” are both hardcoded in the samples analyzed by Microsoft): `C:\Windows\System32\net.exe stop MSSQLSERVER`

Prestige creates C:\Users\Public\README and stores the following ransom note in the file. The same file is also created in the root directory of each drive: 
![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/aea190b3cb4c533a8ebd518942b03ebe3041f3b6909b5439ba96665e05174547.png)

Prestige then traverses the files on the file system and encrypts the contents of files that have specific hardcoded file extensions, avoiding encrypting files in the C:\Windows\ and C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\ directories. 

After encrypting each file, the ransomware appends the extension .enc to the existing extension of the file.

#StopRansomware: LockBit 3.0

objects.name: LockBit
objects.description:
## Summary
LockBit ransomware is one of the most active families in the wild and pretends to implement the fastest encryption algorithms using multithreading with I/O completion ports. LockBit will automatically vet for valuable targets, spread the infection, and encrypt all accessible computer systems on a network. This ransomware is used for highly targeted attacks against enterprises and other organizations. 

LockBit ransomware is considered by many authorities to be part of the “LockerGoga & MegaCortex” malware family. This simply means that it shares behaviors with these established forms of targeted ransomware. As a quick explanation, we understand that these attacks are:
* Self-spreading within an organization rather than requiring manual direction.
* Targeted rather than spread in a scattershot fashion like spam malware.
* Using similar tools to spread, like Windows Powershell and Server Message Block (SMB).

# Technical details
## LockBit 1.0

Most significant is its ability to self-propagate, meaning it spreads on its own. In its programming, LockBit is directed by pre-designed automated processes. This makes it unique from many other ransomware attacks that are driven by manually living in the network — sometimes for weeks — to complete recon and surveillance.

After the attacker has manually infected a single host, it can find other accessible hosts, connect them to infected ones, and share the infection using a script. This is completed and repeated entirely without human intervention.

Furthermore, it uses tools in patterns that are native to nearly all Windows computer systems. Endpoint security systems have a hard time flagging malicious activity. It also hides the executable encrypting file by disguising it as the common .PNG image file format, further deceiving system defenses.

## LockBit 2.0
In July 2021, researchers discovered an analyzed new LockBit samples. Ransomware developpers added a new feature to automatize the process illustrated in _LockBit 1.0_ that consists in deploying scripts that disable antivirus and execute the ransomware on the machines on the network. Now, the ransomware creates new group policies on the domain controller that are then pushed out to every device on a domain controller.

At execution, if privileges are not sufficient, it attempts to escalate to the required privileges. Lockbit 2.0 then determines the system and  user language settings and only targets those not matching a set list of languages that are Eastern European. If an Eastern European language is detected, the program exits without infection.

The ransomware will also use Windows Active Directory APIs to perform LDAP queries against the domain controller's ADS to get a list of computers.

According to Sophos, Lockbit 2.0 and LockFile are similar in at least two ways: the HTA ransom note and the partial encryption.

LockBit 2.0 also contains a self-spreading feature, clears logs and can print the ransom note on network printers until the paper runs out.

## LockBit Linux-ESXi Locker version 1.0

Since October 2021, a Linux variant of LockBit was observed. It seems to be specifically created to lock ESXi servers.
This version of the ransomware has logging capabilities and can log the following information:
* Processor information
* Volumes in the system
* Virtual machines (VMs) for skipping
* Total files
* Total VMs
* Encrypted files
* Encrypted VMs
* Total encrypted size
* Time spent for encryption

## LockBit 3.0 aka LockBit Black
On March 17, 2022, Lockbit ransomware members announced on underground forums they intend to release LockBit 3.0. This new, upgraded version of the malware has already been spotted in malicious campaigns by May 2022 and would be called Lockbit Black by the group itself.

**The LockBit 3.0 version has some code similarities with samples related to the BlackMatter ransomware**. It appears that the code in charge of loading its required functions for both LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter uses API hashing technique with the same hashing algorithm (ror13_add). The algorithm used to import the functions by their hashes is the same for LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter (ror13_add, but with different XOR keys), the hashing algorithm used for the module name is add_ror13. Moreover, both ransomware attempt to hide the main thread from the debugger.

These similarities would raise concerns about a possible link between the gangs behind LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter. Whether the link between the two groups is formal or casual, the code similarities between LockBit 3.0 and BlackMatter are providing additional weight to the hypothesis that different ransomware groups, particularly those of Russian origin, are increasingly interconnected.

-------------------

If a LockBit affiliate does not have access to passwordless LockBit 3.0 ransomware, then a password argument is mandatory during the execution of the ransomware. LockBit 3.0 affiliates failing to enter the correct password will be unable to execute the ransomware. 
The password is a cryptographic key which decodes the LockBit 3.0 executable. By protecting the code in such a manner, LockBit 3.0 hinders malware detection and analysis with the code being unexecutable and unreadable in its encrypted form. 
Signature-based detections may fail to detect the LockBit 3.0 executable as the executable’s encrypted potion will vary based on the cryptographic key used for encryption while also generating a unique hash. When provided the correct password, LockBit 3.0 will decrypt the main component, continue to decrypt or decompress its code, and execute the ransomware.

LockBit 3.0 will only infect machines that do not have language settings matching a defined exclusion list. However, whether a system language is checked at runtime is determined by a configuration flag originally set at compilation time. Languages on the exclusion list include, but are not limited to, Romanian (Moldova), Arabic (Syria), and Tatar (Russia). If a language from the exclusion list is detected, LockBit 3.0 will stop execution without infecting the system.

LockBit 3.0 attempts to spread across a victim network by using a preconfigured list of credentials hardcoded at compilation time or a compromised local account with elevated privileges.
When compiled, LockBit 3.0 may also enable options for spreading via Group Policy Objects and PsExec using the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol. LockBit 3.0 attempts to encrypt data saved to any local or remote device, but skips files associated with core system functions



| **LockBit Parameters** |**Description** | 
| --- |--- |
| -del |Self-delete. | 
| -gdel |Remove LockBit 3.0 group policy changes. | 
| -gspd |Spread laterally via group policy. | 
| -pass (32 character value) |(Required) Password used to launch LockBit 3.0. | 
| -path (File or path) |Only encrypts provided file or folder. | 
| -psex |Spread laterally via admin shares. | 
| -safe |Reboot host into Safe Mode. | 
| -wall |Sets LockBit 3.0 Wallpaper and prints out LockBit 3.0 ransom note. | 


| LockBit 3.0 File Path Locations | 
| --- |
| `ADMIN$\Temp\<LockBit3.0 Filename>.exe` | 
| `%SystemRoot%\Temp\<LockBit3.0 Filename>.exe` | 
| `\<Domain Name>\sysvol\<Domain Name>\scripts\<Lockbit 3.0Filename>.exe (Domain Controller)` | 


###### Services Killed

| vss |sql |svc$ | 
| --- |--- |--- |
| memtas |mepocs |msexchange | 
| sophos |veeam |backup | 
| GxVss |GxBlr |GxFWD | 
| GxCVD |GxCIMgr |  | 

###### Processes Killed
| sql |oracle |ocssd | 
| --- |--- |--- |
| dbsnmp |synctime |agntsvc | 
| isqlplussvc |xfssvccon |mydesktopservice | 
| ocautoupds |encsvc |firefox | 
| tbirdconfig |mydesktopqos |ocomm | 
| dbeng50 |sqbcoreservice |excel | 
| infopath |msaccess |mspu | 
| onenote |outlook |powerpnt | 
| steam |thebat |thunderbird | 
| visio |winword |wordpad | 
| notepad |  |  | 

----------

**LockBit ransomware builder leaked online**

In September 2022, an allegedly developer leaking the builder for the gang's newest encryptor. A threat actor named Ali Quashji claimed on Twitter to have hacked several LockBit’s servers and obtained the LockBit 3.0 builder and the keys generator. Vx-underground, which provides malware samples and other resources, said that they were contacted on September 10th, 2022, by a user named 'protonleaks,' who also shared a copy of the builder.

The leaked zip file contains a folder named “Build,” two executables, one batch, and one JSON file. The builder does not have a Graphical User Interface (GUI) and executes via batch file.

The execution workflow is as follows:
* The “Build.bat” file executes “keygen.exe” and “builder.exe.”  
* “Keygen.exe” is used to generate cryptographic keys.
* “Builder.exe” creates the payload, decryptor, .txt, and other DLL files and saves them to a folder named “Build”.

The leaked LockBit 3.0 builder allows anyone to quickly build the executables required to launch their own operation, including an encryptor, decryptor, and specialized tools to launch the decryptor in certain ways.


## LockBit Green
In late January 2023, vx-underground announced that the LockBit group uses a new ransomware variant - LockBit Green. From ransomware samples shared by Prodaft, the malware was compiled on December 26, 2022.

This is not an in-house developed variant, but a modified pre-existing ransomware. LockBit Green is **based on the leaked source code of the Conti ransomware**.

The **ransom notes** have been modified to use the LockBit 3.0 ransom note rather than Conti's format. Of note, LockBit Green uses a **random extension** rather than the standard .lockbit extension.

external_references.description: CaddyWiper Analysis: New Malware Attacking Ukraine

objects.name: CaddyWiper
objects.description:
CaddyWiper is a wiper first observed by ESET researchers on March 14, 2022, targeting Ukraine during the Ukraine-Russia conflict. It is the fourth wiper used during this conflict after WhisperGate, HermeticWiper, and IsaacWiper. The wiper erases user data and partition information from attached drives. CaddyWiper was observed deployed via GPO indicating that the threat actor probably compromised the Active Directory server. CaddyWiper avoids destroying data on domain controllers. This is probably a way for the attackers to keep their access inside the organization while still disturbing operations.

According to ESET, "TailJump", a variant of CaddyWiper has been used on April 8, 2022 during an attack against an Ukrainian energy company, in parallel of the malware Industroyer2, which has been developped by the Sandworm intrusion set. Therefore, it is strongly likely that CaddyWiper has been developped by the Sandworm intrusion set. This version is a slightly modified version of CaddyWiper encrypted using a single-byte XOR key. This version is loaded and decrypted by ARGUEPATCH.

CaddyWiper does not share any significant code similarity with HermeticWiper or IsaacWiper, two wiper that appear in the same context. The samples are not digitally signed.

external_references.description: DDosia Project: How NoName057(16) is trying to improve the efficiency of DDoS attacks
Following NoName057(16) DDoSia Project’s Targets

objects.name: DDoSia
objects.description:
**DDoSia** is a DDoS attack toolkit, devleopped and used by pro Russia hacktivist nationalist group [NoName057(16)](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--b64214ae-c74f-49a5-a979-c2f36d581247) against countries critical of Russian invasion of Ukraine.

DDoSia project was launched on Telegram, where operators posted a link to GitHub with instructions for potential “volunteers”. The group's main Telegram channel reached more than 13,000 subscribers but only 400 are active participants.

DDoSia volunteers register via Telegram to receive a ZIP archive with malware (dosia.exe) that contains a unique ID for each user. The most interesting feature of this project is the fact that participants can link their ID to a cryptocurrency wallet and receive money for participating in DDoS attacks. Moreover, payment is proportional to the capacities provided by a particular participant.

## DDoSia Description

According to Avast, the first version of DDoSia was written in Python using threads as a means of parallelism; nevertheless, it was still lacking in terms of efficacy. Since the first version, DDoSia relied on HTTP protocol for C2 communication, with JSON configs distributed by the servers. The lack of efficacy presumably motivated changes in DDOSIA, namely the move from Python to Go that Avast saw in late 2022.

These new versions are also multi-platform, as Avast have seen variants for all major operating systems (Windows, macOS, Linux, Android). Evidently, the bot development is still in progress, as Avast see new functionalities, such as HTTP authentication, being added to DDOSIA along with slight changes in the configuration file.

The names of the executable are changed sometimes; there is a list of the captured names:

* `dosia_app_(windows|macos|linux)_(x64|arm64)`
* `d_(win|mac|linux)_(x64|arm64)`
* `pd_(win|mac|linux)_(x64|arm64)`
* `dosia_(win|mac|linux)_(x64|arm64)`

A working dir of the bot executable must contain a text file `client_id.txt` with the User-Hash of the registered user. The form of the User-Hash is a BCrypt hash with these parameters `$2a$16$`.
The first outcome communication is to use `nordvpn.com` to get detailed information about the bot IP address that is sent to the C2 server. The second outcome is to use C2 as a POST method to `/login` URL with data representing information about the bot IP, user ID, and bot identification.

If the authentication is successful, C2 returns `HTTP/1.1 200` OK with a token in the form of epoch/Unix timestamp, and the target configuration can then be downloaded via `GET /client/get_targets`. 

The new configuration supports four attack types: `http`, `http2`, `nginx_loris`, and `tcp`.

Continuous statistics are sent each ~four minutes back to the C2 server through `POST /set_attack_count`.

![](/api/v2/inthreat/images/2589e16724bbe499f8c461c8b7782001e2221c1d1c06369327557e36af7cd572.png)

external_references.description: Treasury Sanctions Russian Government Research Institution Connected to the Triton Malware
Attackers Deploy New ICS Attack Framework “TRITON” and Cause Operational Disruption to Critical Infrastructure
TRITON Actor TTP Profile, Custom Attack Tools, Detections, and ATT&CK Mapping
Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures of Indicted State-Sponsored Russian Cyber Actors Targeting the Energy Sector

objects.name: Triton
objects.description:
The Triton malware was developed to target and manipulate industrial safety systems.
FireEye has linked the malware to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB).

The malware was first discovered following a cyberattack on a Saudi petrochemical plant in August 2017. Nonetheless, a bug in the code prevented the malware from achieving the intended damage because it triggered an emergency shutdown of critical systems. The attackers' goal was potentially to cause the explosion of the plant.

TRITON malware has multiple components, including a custom Python script, four Python modules, and malicious shellcode that contains an injector and a payload

Triton malware is capable of reprogramming Triconex Safety Instrumented System (SIS) controllers manufactured by Schneider Electric. These controllers are part of the last line of defense to prevent critical failures and possible disasters in industrial facilities. They are designed to automatically shut down equipment and processes if they exceed safe operating parameters.

On March 24, 2022, the U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indicments of a Russian Federation Central Scientific Research Institute of Chemistry and Mechanics (TsNIIKhM) employee which was a co-conspirator in the deployment of the TRITON malware in 2017. As of this date though, CISA, FBI and DOE have no information whether this actor has intentionally disrupted any U.S. Energy Sector infrastructure.

objects.name: Mallox
objects.description:
**Mallox** (also known as **Fargo** and **TargetCompany**) is a ransomware strain active since mid-June 2021 (June 12, 2021, if we look back at the oldest sample Sekoia.io could collect in open source), and one of the prominent ransomware families targeting unsecured MS-SQL servers. It is owned by the [Mallox ransomware group](/intelligence/objects/intrusion-set--82c5df07-1752-4570-9aa1-fe1f236be559) who declared it acquired the project from another threat group.

According to ID-Ransomware and BleepingComputer, the Mallox ransomware was distributed under the **`mawahelper `** identity since at least February 2023.

In June 2023, AhnLab observed a version of the Mallox ransomware with the .bat file extension used to encrypt data of poorly managed MS-SQL servers.

## Initial Access
Database servers are often compromised through brute-force and dictionary attacks that are successful against accounts protected with weak credentials. Alternatively, cybercriminals try to exploit known vulnerabilities that the target has not patched.

In June 2023, Mallox was reported beying deployed using BatLoader.

As of August 2023, the intrusion set is reported to mainly exploit vulnerable SQL Servers to gain access.

 ## Background
This malware family is reffering to as **Mallox** because it used to append the “.mallox” extension to the files it encrypts since at least October 2021, but it was also recently tracked as **Fargo** by security researchers.

The ransomware actors also use the name Mallox in their ransom notes, on their Mallox-branded DLS (Data Leak Site) on TOR and on other platforms such as Twitter or Telegram.

Also, this strain is the same that Avast researchers named **TargetCompany** in a report in February 2022, highlighting that files encrypted by it may be recovered for free in some cases.

## Infection and execution
The ransomware infection starts with the MS-SQL process on the compromised machine downloading a .NET file using cmd.exe and powershell.exe.

The payload fetches additional malware (including the locker), generates and runs a BAT file that terminates specific processes and services.

Next, the ransomware payload injects itself into AppLaunch.exe, a legitimate Windows process, and tries to delete the registry key for the open-source ransomware “vaccine” called Raccine.

Additionally, the malware executes the recovery deactivation command and terminates database-related processes to make their contents available for encryption.

## Encryption

When the ransomware encrypts files, files with file extensions shown below are excluded from infection. The characteristic aspect is that it does not infect files with a file extension associated with [Globeimposter](/intelligence/objects/malware--3cade096-ad69-40c1-8034-58fe56090ca0). This exclusion list does not only include the same type of extensions of .FARGO .FARGO2 and .FARGO3 but also includes .FARGO4, which is thought to be a future version of the ransomware.

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/3cf996a9d6b9aab064c18ed7c179ee13b212f05eb029757919ac30cc51d07460.png)
Figure: Extensions excluded from infection. Source: ASEC.

After the encryption completes, the locked files are renamed using the “.Fargo3” extension (`OriginalFileName.FileExtension.Fargo3`). Other known extensions added to the encrypted files are: `.mallox`, `.exploit`, `.architek`, `.brg`, `.herrco`, `.artiis`, `xollam`, `mawahelper`, `.malox` and others.

Those extensions would sometimes include the name of the attacked company. For some ransomware campaigns, Mallox uses any victim name as extension to an unrelated attack to confuse the victim and the security researchers.

In the group's words, each major ransomware update comes with a change in the extension, "since the encryption algorithm changed and it was required to use decryptors with different characteristics".

## Mallox Ransom Note and Ransom Demands
The ransom note is generated with the filename `RECOVERY FILES.txt` (ASEC, September 2022), `HOW TO RECOVER !!.TXT` (Avast, February 2022), `FILE RECOVERY.txt` (SEKOIA.IO, December 2022), `How to decrypt files.txt` (id-ransomware.blogspot.com, April 2023)

The ransom note contains instructions on how to contact the attackers. It urges victims to contact them via their TOR live chat (since at least October 2022) by logging in with a given personal ID, or to send it to a specific email address.

The ransom demands have been reported to range from $1000 to $50,000. Sekoia.io found that in the case of a Colombian-based victim, the ransom amount was reduced from $50,000 to $20,000 within a two-week period.

## Ransomware decryptor tool
In February 2022, the cybersecurity software firm Avast has released a free decryptor tool that facilitate victims of the TargetCompany ransomware in recovering files without paying the ransom demand. However, the free utilities (decryptor tools) are limited; the features can only be used to recover encrypted files “under certain circumstances.” 

## Double Extorsion
In the ransom notes from late 2021 - early 2022 seen by Sekoia.io, the Mallox ransomware actors only asked for a ransom to decrypt victims' data.

Later in 2022, the group started to communicate about its double extortion tactic by threatening to publish the victims' stolen data initially on Twitter (starting from August 2022) and Telegram: "In case of non-payment of the ransom, your data may be published in the public domain".

Then beginning from November 2022, Mallox started to use a dedicated TOR site for double extorsion. When a victim does not pay the ransom, the exfiltrated data is released on the group's public data leak site. 

**Mallox public data leak platforms**:
* `Mallox Data Leaks` aka `Mallox|Blog`: hxxp://wtyafjyhwqrgo4a45wdvvwhen3cx4euie73qvlhkhvlrexljoyuklaad[.]onion (embedded in ransom notes since November 2022, created on November 1st, 2022 or earlier)
* Mallox Telegram channel with data leaks: hxxps://t[.]me/mallox_leaks
* Mallox Twitter account with data leaks 1: hxxps://twitter[.]com/mallox_leaks (from August to mid-October 2022, currently suspended)
* Mallox Twitter account with data leaks 2: `hxxps://twitter[.]com/___Mallox___` (created in August 2022)

![](https://app.sekoia.io/api/v2/inthreat/images/f28a2aa6d0ab1656b8be0b3d0ab7ca4eb5a0562fbb48399865e891fa00c70692.png)
Figure: Mallox DLS. Source: Sekoia.io, November 2022.

objects.name: Shamoon
objects.description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) is wiper malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. Other versions known as Shamoon 2 and Shamoon 3 were observed in 2016 and 2018. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has also been seen leveraging [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) and Filerase to carry out data wiping tasks. The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)

objects.name: Nexus
objects.description:
# Stealer :

The product is implemented in C / C ++. During development, attention was focused on maximum fault tolerance, availability and the vastness of the data collected. Convenient WEB - Panel, designed specifically for productive work with large amounts of data, allowing you to sort your logs by a large number of criteria, obtaining the result without any extraneous manipulations.

## Fonctionnality : 

* Data collection of all Chromium browsers (Passwords, Credit cards, Cookies, AutoFill forms, Browsing history, Download history, Search engine history) Including data from Yandex-Browser and browsers with non-standard data location.
* Collecting all .dat files (recursion) of cryptocurrency wallets, as well as collecting cold wallets: Anoncoin, Bitcoin, Bitpay, Coinomi, DashCore, devcoin, Eidoo, Electrum, Electrum-NMC, Exodus, Feathercoin, Fetch, FLO, Franko, Freicoin, GoldCoin (GLD), Guarda, I0coin, iXcoin, Jaxx, Litecoin, Luckycoin, MegaCoin, Mincoin, Monero, MyCrypto, NovaCoin, Peercoin, Primecoin, Quarkcoin, TerracoinCore, Worldcoin, Yacoin, Zetacoin.
* 2FA Session Collection - Authenticator (Authy)
* Collect all Telegram sessions
* Collect All Discord Sessions
* Collection of Jabber client correspondence
* Collecting All Steam Sessions
* Collecting all FileZilla profiles
* Collection of all WinSCP profiles
* Collect all TotalCommander profiles
* WindowsSecureVault Credential Collection
* IE Credential Collection, Edge
* Collecting All Pidgin Accounts
* Collection of all PSI, PSI + accounts
* VPN client session collection
* Collection of system information, screenshots and geolocation data (useful for spot processing of the client)
* Grabber file
* Ability to filter CIS-Logs, repetition protection
* There is a Loader module with flexible parameters, the ability to specify multiple files at once and many filters
* A separate and convenient search page, with the ability to sort by a large number of criteria, including cookies and passwords, which allows you to automate the search for the necessary data.
* The ability to change the theme in one click
* View log data without downloading (passwords, PC information)
* Intuitive and at the same time beautiful admin panel. Ability to sort logs by user templates (Presets), the ability to create / edit / delete templates.
* The ability to download or delete all the logs directly in the panel (in one click)!
* Smart filtering of fresh logs
* Geostatistical information on the main page
* Regular updates according to the wishes of customers. We always try to implement what our users want.
